Preface by Xu Ai

Regarding the Master's various teachings on "the investigation of things" in the Great Learning, he consistently took the old text as authoritative — what earlier Confucians had called the "erroneous edition." When Ai first heard this, he was startled; then he doubted it; but finally, after exhausting his thought and deliberation, cross-referencing and comparing from every angle, and questioning the Master directly, he came to understand that the Master's teachings are as certain as the coldness of water or the heat of fire — absolutely beyond doubt, such that "one could wait a hundred generations for a sage and not be confused." The Master's brilliance and perspicacity were Heaven-bestowed, yet he was harmonious, joyful, open, and unaffected, never putting on airs. People who knew of his bold and unrestrained youth, and that he had once indulged in literary composition and explored Buddhist and Daoist learning, upon suddenly hearing these teachings, all dismissed them as eccentric novelties and would not trouble themselves to examine them. They did not know that during his three years of exile among the barbarians, dwelling in hardship and cultivating stillness, his effort at refined singleness had already transcended into the realm of sagehood, arriving at the pure, great mean of utmost correctness.

Ai, basking daily in the Master's presence, saw only this of the Master's Way: approach it and it seems easy, yet look up and it grows ever loftier; view it and it seems coarse, yet probe it and it grows ever more refined; draw near and it seems close, yet pursue it and it proves ever more inexhaustible. Over more than ten years, I have never been able to glimpse even its outer boundaries. Yet the gentlemen of this age — some having met the Master only once, some never having heard his voice, some harboring from the start a mind of dismissal or indignation — presume in the space of a brief conversation, based on hearsay, to make arbitrary judgments and groundless conjectures. How can this possibly succeed? Among those who have traveled and studied with him, upon hearing the Master's teachings they often grasp one part and lose two; they see the surface color of the horse and discard what makes it a thousand-li steed. Therefore Ai has compiled a complete record of what he has heard on ordinary days, and privately shares it with like-minded friends, so that together we may examine and correct it, and thus not fail the Master's teachings.

Written by his disciple Xu Ai.

The following was recorded by the disciple Xu Ai.

Ai asked: "Regarding 'abiding in loving the people,' Zhu Xi held that it should read 'renewing the people,' and the phrase 'inspiring the people to renew themselves' in the later chapter seems to provide evidence for this. The Master considers that it should follow the old text as 'loving the people' — is there also a basis for this?"

The Master said: "The 'renew' in 'inspiring the people to renew themselves' means 'the people who renew themselves,' which is different from the 'renew' in 'abiding in renewing the people.' How can this serve as evidence? The character 'inspire' actually corresponds to the character 'love,' but it is not the meaning of 'renew.' In the subsequent passages on 'ordering the state and bringing peace to the world,' there is no elaboration on the meaning of 'renew.' For instance, 'The gentleman treats as worthy those whom he finds worthy and loves those who are his kin; the petty person delights in what delights him and profits from what profits him,' 'As one would protect an infant,' and 'What the people love, love it; what the people hate, hate it — this is called being a parent to the people' — all these convey the meaning of 'love.' 'Loving the people' is like what Mencius called 'loving one's kin and being humane to the people' — 'to love them' is 'to be humane toward them.' When 'the hundred clans were not affectionate toward one another,' Shun appointed Xie as Minister of Education to 'reverently spread the five teachings,' in order to make them love one another. In the Canon of Yao, 'able to manifest lofty virtue' is 'manifesting luminous virtue,' and 'being affectionate to the nine degrees of kindred' through 'harmonizing and making concordant' is 'loving the people' — it is 'manifesting luminous virtue throughout the world.' Again, as Confucius said, 'Cultivating oneself so as to bring peace to the hundred clans' — 'cultivating oneself' is 'manifesting luminous virtue,' and 'bringing peace to the hundred clans' is 'loving the people.' To speak of 'loving the people' encompasses both the meaning of instruction and nurture. To speak of 'renewing the people' seems one-sided."

Ai asked: "Regarding 'knowing where to rest, and then having stability,' Zhu Xi interpreted this as 'each and every thing has its fixed principle.' This seems to contradict the Master's teaching."

The Master said: "To seek the highest good in each and every thing is to place righteousness outside oneself. The highest good is the original substance of the mind. It is simply 'manifesting luminous virtue' brought to the point of utmost refinement and singleness. Yet it has never departed from things and affairs. What the original commentary calls 'exhausting the Principle of Heaven to the utmost, without a hair's breadth of selfish desire' captures it."

Ai asked: "If the highest good is sought only in the mind, I fear one cannot exhaust all the principles of things in the world."

The Master said: "The mind is principle. Can there be any affair outside the mind, or any principle outside the mind?"

Ai said: "In matters such as filial piety in serving one's father, loyalty in serving one's ruler, trustworthiness in dealing with friends, and humaneness in governing the people — in each of these there are many principles. I fear these too cannot be left unexamined."

The Master sighed and said: "This view has obscured people for a long time. How can it be dispelled in a single statement? Let me now address what you have asked. Take serving one's father — you cannot go to your father to seek the principle of filial piety. Take serving one's ruler — you cannot go to your ruler to seek the principle of loyalty. Take dealing with friends or governing the people — you cannot go to friends or to the people to seek the principles of trustworthiness and humaneness. All of these reside solely in this mind. The mind is principle. When this mind is free from the obscuration of selfish desires, it is the Principle of Heaven itself — nothing needs to be added from outside. With this mind that is purely the Principle of Heaven: when it is directed toward serving one's father, it is filial piety; when directed toward serving one's ruler, it is loyalty; when directed toward dealing with friends or governing the people, it is trustworthiness and humaneness. One need only exert effort on this mind in 'removing selfish desires and preserving the Principle of Heaven.'"

Ai said: "Hearing the Master explain it this way, I already feel some awakening. But the old theories still entangle my mind, and there are things I have not yet fully shed. For instance, in the matter of serving one's father, there are many specific duties such as keeping him warm in winter and cool in summer, inquiring after his health morning and evening. Must these not also be studied and inquired into?"

The Master said: "How could you not study and inquire into them? The point is simply that there must be a guiding principle — it is simply a matter of exerting effort on this mind in 'removing selfish desires and preserving the Principle of Heaven.' For example, in studying 'keeping him warm in winter,' it is only about fully realizing this mind's filial piety, fearing that the slightest selfish desire might intrude. In studying 'keeping him cool in summer,' it is likewise only about fully realizing this mind's filial piety, fearing that the slightest selfish desire might intrude. It is only about attending to this mind. If this mind has no selfish desires and is purely the Principle of Heaven — if it is a mind sincerely devoted to loving one's parents — then in winter one will naturally think about one's parents feeling cold, and will naturally seek ways to keep them warm; in summer one will naturally think about one's parents feeling hot, and will naturally seek ways to keep them cool. These are all specific expressions that issue from that sincere filial mind. But one must first have this sincere filial mind, and only then will these specific expressions issue forth. It is like a tree: the sincere filial mind is the root, and the many specific duties are the branches and leaves. One must first have the root, and then there will be branches and leaves. One does not first find branches and leaves and then plant the root. The Record of Rites says: 'A filial son who has deep love will surely have a harmonious disposition. One with a harmonious disposition will surely have a joyful expression. One with a joyful expression will surely have a gentle countenance.' One must have 'deep love' as the root, and then these naturally follow."

Zheng Chaoshuo asked: "Must not the highest good also be sought in things and affairs?"

The Master said: "The highest good is simply this mind being purely the Principle of Heaven to the utmost. How could one seek it further in things and affairs? Try giving me some examples."

Chaoshuo said: "For instance, in serving one's parents: what constitutes the proper measure of keeping them warm and cool, what constitutes appropriate care and nourishment — one must seek what is fitting, and only then is it the highest good. This is why there is the effort of learning, questioning, thinking, and discerning."

The Master said: "If it is merely the proper measures of warmth and coolness, the appropriate forms of care and nourishment, these could be fully explained in a day or two. What need would there be for learning, questioning, thinking, and discerning? The point is precisely this: when keeping them warm, one must ensure that this mind is purely the Principle of Heaven to the utmost; when providing nourishment, one must ensure that this mind is purely the Principle of Heaven to the utmost. Without the effort of learning, questioning, thinking, and discerning, one will inevitably fall into errors of a hair's breadth that lead to deviations of a thousand miles. This is why even sages still added the instruction of 'refinement and singleness.' If one merely seeks to get the ceremonial details right and calls that the highest good, then even an actor who performs all the ceremonies of warming, cooling, and nourishing correctly could be said to have achieved the highest good." On this day, Ai had another moment of awakening.

Ai, not yet having understood the Master's teaching of "the unity of knowledge and action," went back and forth debating with Zongxian and Weixian without reaching a resolution, and brought the question to the Master.

The Master said: "Try presenting your case."

Ai said: "There are people today who fully know that one should be filial to one's father and respectful to one's elder brother, yet they cannot be filial or respectful. This clearly shows that knowledge and action are two separate things."

The Master said: "This is already a case where selfish desires have created a separation. This is not the original substance of knowledge and action. There has never been a case of knowing without acting. To know and not act is simply not yet to truly know. When the sages and worthies taught people about knowledge and action, it was precisely to restore that original substance — not to tell you that just this much is sufficient. Therefore the Great Learning points out true knowledge and action for people to see, saying 'like loving a lovely sight, like hating a hateful smell.' Seeing a lovely sight belongs to knowledge; loving the lovely sight belongs to action. But the moment one sees the lovely sight, one already loves it — it is not that one sees it first and then separately sets up an intention to love it. Smelling a hateful smell belongs to knowledge; hating the hateful smell belongs to action. The moment one smells the hateful smell, one already hates it — it is not that one smells it first and then separately sets up an intention to hate it. A person with a stuffed nose, though a hateful smell be right before him, does not really smell it, and so does not particularly hate it — this is simply a case of not truly knowing the smell. When we say someone knows filial piety or knows brotherly respect, it must be because that person has already practiced filial piety or brotherly respect — only then can we call them knowing filial piety or brotherly respect. It is not that merely being able to say some words about filial piety or brotherly respect qualifies as knowing them. Knowing pain means one has already felt pain; knowing cold means one has already felt cold; knowing hunger means one has already felt hunger. How can knowledge and action be separated? This is the original substance of knowledge and action, before selfish intentions have created any separation. The sages taught people that it must be like this before it can be called knowledge — otherwise it is simply not yet knowing. What urgent and practical effort this represents! Now people insist on making knowledge and action into two separate things — what is the purpose? When I say they are one — what is the purpose? If one does not understand the fundamental aim of the teaching, what use is it to keep arguing about whether they are one or two?"

Ai said: "The ancients spoke of knowledge and action as two in order to help people see them clearly — one line of effort for knowledge, one line of effort for action — so that the effort would have a place to land."

The Master said: "This misses the fundamental aim of the ancients. I have often said: knowledge is the direction of action; action is the effort of knowledge. Knowledge is the beginning of action; action is the completion of knowledge. If one truly understands this, then speaking only of knowledge already includes action within it; speaking only of action already includes knowledge within it. The reason the ancients spoke of both knowledge and action is simply this: there are people in the world who act in a muddled, confused way, doing as they please without any thought or self-examination — this is mere reckless, heedless action. Therefore one must speak of knowledge before action can be correct. There are also people who think in a vague, drifting, ungrounded way, never willing to earnestly put things into practice — this is mere speculation and guesswork. Therefore one must speak of action before knowledge can be genuine. This was the ancients' unavoidable remedy for one-sidedness. If one grasps this meaning, a single word suffices. But people today have taken knowledge and action and divided them into two separate tasks, thinking that one must first know and only then can one act. They say: 'Let me first devote myself to study and discussion as the effort of knowledge, and wait until I truly know before I undertake the effort of action.' Thus they end up never acting their whole lives, and consequently never truly knowing their whole lives. This is no small ailment, and it has been going on for a long time. My present teaching of the unity of knowledge and action is precisely the medicine for this disease. It is not something I have fabricated out of nothing — the original substance of knowledge and action is truly like this. If one understands the fundamental aim, then speaking of them as two does no harm either — they are still one. If one does not grasp the fundamental aim, even speaking of them as one, what good does it do? It is just idle talk."

Ai asked: "Yesterday, hearing the Master's teaching on 'resting in the highest good,' I already felt my effort had a place to take hold. But when I think about it alongside Zhu Xi's explanation of 'the investigation of things,' I ultimately cannot reconcile them."

The Master said: "'The investigation of things' is the effort of 'resting in the highest good.' Once you understand 'the highest good,' you understand 'the investigation of things.'"

Ai said: "Yesterday, extending the Master's teaching to the doctrine of 'the investigation of things,' I seemed to see its general outline. But Zhu Xi's explanation, which finds corroboration in the 'refinement and singleness' of the Book of Documents, the 'breadth and restraint' of the Analerta, and the 'fully developing the mind and knowing one's nature' of Mencius — because of these I have not been able to feel at ease."

The Master said: "Zixia placed firm trust in the sage; Zengzi sought within himself. Firm trust is certainly good, but it is not as urgent as seeking within oneself. Now that you cannot find satisfaction in your own mind, how can you cling to old learning without seeking what is right? Even Zhu Xi, who revered and trusted the Cheng brothers, did not simply go along with them on points where he could not find satisfaction in his own mind. 'Refinement and singleness,' 'breadth and restraint,' and 'fully developing the mind' are in themselves perfectly consistent with my teaching — you simply have not thought it through. Zhu Xi's explanation of 'the investigation of things' cannot avoid being forced and contrived, not capturing the original meaning. Refinement is the effort of singleness; breadth is the effort of restraint. Once you clearly understand the teaching of the unity of knowledge and action, this can be explained in a single statement. 'Fully developing the mind, knowing one's nature, and knowing Heaven' describes the stage of 'those who know through birth and practice with ease.' 'Preserving the mind, nourishing one's nature, and serving Heaven' describes the stage of 'those who know through learning and practice for advantage.' 'Not being of two minds about longevity or early death, and cultivating one's person while awaiting destiny' describes the stage of 'those who know through difficulty and practice through exertion.' Zhu Xi mistakenly interpreted 'the investigation of things' only because he read this passage in reverse, taking 'fully developing the mind and knowing one's nature' to be 'things being investigated and knowledge being extended,' and thus expecting beginning students to do what pertains to 'those who know through birth and practice with ease.' How can this be done?"

Ai asked: "Why does 'fully developing the mind and knowing one's nature' pertain to 'knowing through birth and practicing with ease'?"

The Master said: "Nature is the substance of the mind; Heaven is the source of nature. Fully developing the mind is fully developing one's nature. 'Only the most sincere under Heaven can fully develop his nature' and 'know the transformative processes of Heaven and Earth.' 'Preserving the mind' implies the mind has not been fully developed. 'Knowing Heaven' is like 'knowing' in 'the magistrate of a prefecture' or 'the magistrate of a county' — it refers to one's own responsibility; oneself and Heaven are one. 'Serving Heaven' is like a son serving his father or a minister serving his ruler — one must be reverent and compliant, and only then can one avoid error. Here one is still separate from Heaven. This is the distinction between sage and worthy. As for 'not being of two minds about longevity or early death,' this teaches students to be single-minded in doing good, not to let considerations of success or failure, longevity or early death, alter their resolve to do good. One simply cultivates oneself and awaits destiny, recognizing that success, failure, longevity, and early death are matters of destiny, and one need not let them disturb one's mind. 'Serving Heaven,' though still being separate from Heaven, already sees Heaven before one's face. 'Awaiting destiny' is like not yet having met face to face and waiting in attendance. This is the beginning of establishing one's mind in learning, with the sense of difficulty and exertion in it. Yet now people do it in reverse, which is why students have no place to begin their effort."

Ai said: "Yesterday hearing the Master's teaching, I vaguely perceived that the effort must be like this. Now hearing this explanation, I have no more doubts. Yesterday at dawn I was thinking about the 'things' in 'the investigation of things' — this 'things' is the same as 'affairs,' and both are spoken of from the perspective of the mind."

The Master said: "Correct. The master of the body is the mind; what the mind issues forth is intention; the original substance of intention is knowledge; and where intention is directed is things. For example, when intention is directed toward serving one's parents, then serving one's parents is a 'thing'; when intention is directed toward serving one's ruler, then serving one's ruler is a 'thing'; when intention is directed toward being humane to the people or caring for creatures, then being humane to the people or caring for creatures is a 'thing'; when intention is directed toward seeing, hearing, speaking, or moving, then seeing, hearing, speaking, or moving is a 'thing.' Therefore I say there is no principle outside the mind, and no thing outside the mind. The Doctrine of the Mean says 'without sincerity there are no things.' The effort of 'manifesting luminous virtue' in the Great Learning is simply 'making the intentions sincere.' The effort of 'making the intentions sincere' is simply 'the investigation of things.'"

The Master further said: "'The investigation of things' — 'investigate' here is like in Mencius's phrase 'the great man rectifies the ruler's mind.' It means to remove what is incorrect in the mind, in order to preserve the correctness of its original substance. Wherever one's thoughts and intentions are directed, one must remove their incorrectness to preserve their correctness. This means there is no time or place that is not a matter of preserving the Principle of Heaven — and this is 'exhaustively investigating principle.' 'The Principle of Heaven' is 'luminous virtue'; 'exhaustively investigating principle' is 'manifesting luminous virtue.'"

He further said: "Knowledge is the original substance of the mind. The mind naturally knows. Seeing one's father, one naturally knows filial piety; seeing one's elder brother, one naturally knows respect; seeing a child fall into a well, one naturally knows compassion. This is innate knowing — it need not be sought outside. If the issuing of innate knowing is free from the obstruction of selfish intentions, then it is what is called 'extending one's feeling of compassion, and humaneness becomes inexhaustible.' However, in ordinary people, selfish intentions inevitably create obstructions. Therefore one must use the effort of 'extending knowledge' and 'investigating things.' Once selfish desires are overcome and principle is restored, the mind's innate knowing is no longer obstructed and can fill and flow freely — this is extending one's knowledge. When knowledge is extended, then intentions become sincere."

Ai asked: "The Master takes 'broad learning in culture' as the effort of 'restraining oneself with ritual.' I have thought deeply about this but cannot grasp it. Please give me a brief explanation."

The Master said: "The character 'ritual' is the same as the character 'principle.' The visible manifestation of principle is called 'culture'; the hidden and subtle aspect of culture that cannot be seen is called 'principle.' They are one and the same thing. 'Restraining oneself with ritual' simply means making this mind purely the Principle of Heaven. To make this mind purely the Principle of Heaven, one must exert effort where principle manifests itself. When it manifests in serving one's parents, one studies and preserves the Principle of Heaven in serving one's parents. When it manifests in serving one's ruler, one studies and preserves the Principle of Heaven in serving one's ruler. When it manifests in situations of wealth and honor, poverty and lowliness, one studies and preserves the Principle of Heaven in those situations. When it manifests in situations of hardship and adversity, one studies and preserves the Principle of Heaven in those situations. In all activities and stillness, speech and silence, there is nowhere this does not apply. Wherever principle manifests, right there one studies and preserves the Principle of Heaven. This is 'learning broadly in culture' — it is the effort of 'restraining oneself with ritual.' 'Broad learning in culture' is 'refinement'; 'restraining oneself with ritual' is 'singleness.'"

Ai asked: "The statement 'the moral mind always serves as master of the person, and the human mind always obeys its commands' — extending it through the Master's teaching on 'refinement and singleness,' this statement seems to have a flaw."

The Master said: "Indeed. The mind is one. Before it is mixed with the human element, it is called 'the moral mind'; when mixed with human artifice, it is called 'the human mind.' When 'the human mind' attains its correctness, it is 'the moral mind'; when 'the moral mind' loses its correctness, it is 'the human mind.' There were never originally two minds. Cheng Yi said: 'The human mind is selfish desire; the moral mind is the Principle of Heaven.' His words seem to divide them, but his meaning truly captures it. Now to say 'the moral mind serves as master, while the human mind obeys its commands' is to posit two minds. The Principle of Heaven and selfish desires do not stand together — how can there be the Principle of Heaven as master while selfish desires also follow and obey commands?"

Ai asked about Wang Tong (Wenzhongzi) and Han Yu (Han Tuizhi).

The Master said: "Han Yu was merely the greatest among literary men; Wang Tong was a worthy Confucian. Later people, merely because of literary talent, have elevated Han Yu, but in truth Han Yu falls far short of Wang Tong."

Ai asked: "What about his transgression of imitating the classics?"

The Master said: "Imitating the classics cannot be entirely condemned. Let me ask: how does the intent behind later Confucians' writings compare with imitating the classics?"

Ai said: "The writings of later Confucians are not without the desire for fame, but they aim to illuminate the Way. Imitating the classics seems purely done for fame."

The Master said: "If writing is meant to illuminate the Way, what does it take as its model?"

Ai said: "Confucius edited and transmitted the Six Classics to illuminate the Way."

The Master said: "Then is not imitating the classics also modeling oneself on Confucius?"

Ai said: "Writing can contribute something to the illumination of the Way. Imitating the classics seems merely to imitate its outward form, and likely contributes nothing to the Way."

The Master said: "By illuminating the Way, do you mean causing people to return to simplicity and genuineness, manifested in actual conduct? Or do you mean embellishing one's words to engage in noisy argument with the world? The great disorder of the world stems from the triumph of empty rhetoric over genuine practice. If the Way were illuminated throughout the world, the Six Classics would not need to be transmitted. Confucius's editing and transmitting of the Six Classics was something he did out of necessity. From Fu Xi's drawing of the hexagrams down to King Wen and the Duke of Zhou, the various texts about the Changes — such as the Lianshan and the Guizang — were countless and innumerable, and the Way of the Changes fell into great disorder. Confucius, knowing that the world's love of rhetoric was daily increasing and that such explanations would become limitless, selected the explanations of King Wen and the Duke of Zhou and commented on them, taking only these as having grasped the essential principle. Thereupon all the confused explanations were abandoned, and the world's discourse on the Changes became unified. The same was true of the Documents, the Odes, the Rites, the Music, and the Spring and Autumn Annals. After the Canons and Counsels in the Documents, after the Two Nan in the Odes — works like the Nine Hills and the Eight Cords, and all manner of licentious and dissolute writings, numbered in the hundreds and thousands. The names, categories, and numerical details of the Rites and Music had also become inexhaustible. Confucius deleted and edited all of these, after which those other teachings ceased. In the Documents, Odes, Rites, and Music, did Confucius ever add a single word of his own? The present Record of Rites and its various commentaries were all pieced together by later Confucians — they are no longer what Confucius left. As for the Spring and Autumn Annals, though it is said Confucius composed it, in reality it consists entirely of the old texts of the Lu state histories. What is called 'writing' was writing down what was already there; what is called 'deleting' was deleting what was superfluous — there was reduction but no addition. Confucius transmitted the Six Classics out of fear that excessive writing would disorder the world. He only sought to simplify, intending to make the world eliminate rhetoric in order to seek substance — not to teach through rhetoric. After the Spring and Autumn period, excessive writing proliferated further, and the world grew ever more disordered. The First Emperor's burning of books was criminal, being motivated by private interest, and he should not have burned the Six Classics. But had his aim been to illuminate the Way, burning all the writings that violated the classics and opposed principle would actually have been in accord with the spirit of Confucius's editing and transmitting. Since the Qin and Han dynasties, writing has daily proliferated. To attempt to eliminate it all would be impossible. The best approach would be to follow Confucius's example, selecting what comes closest to truth and honoring it, so that the various bizarre and perverse theories would gradually fall into disuse of their own accord. I do not know what Wang Tong's intent was in imitating the classics, but I deeply approve of what he did, believing that even if a sage arose again, he could not improve upon it. The reason the world is not well governed is simply because empty rhetoric has triumphed and genuine practice has declined. People put forth their own views, each trying to outdo the other in novelty, to dazzle the vulgar and win fame, merely confounding the world's intelligence, clogging the world's eyes and ears, making the whole world rush to embellish their rhetoric in order to gain recognition, no longer knowing the practice of attending to fundamentals, honoring substance, and returning to simplicity. It is all the fault of those who write."

Ai said: "Some writings are indispensable. For example, without the Zuo Commentary, the Spring and Autumn Annals would be difficult to understand."

The Master said: "If the Spring and Autumn Annals requires the Commentary before it can be understood, then it is a riddle with the punchline withheld. Why would a sage deliberately write in such obscure and difficult terms? The Zuo Commentary largely consists of the old texts of the Lu state histories. If the Spring and Autumn Annals needs these to be understood, why did Confucius delete them?"

Ai said: "Cheng Yi also said: 'The Commentary provides the case; the Classic provides the verdict.' If one merely writes 'murdered such-and-such a ruler' or 'attacked such-and-such a state,' without making the affair clear, the verdict would indeed be difficult."

The Master said: "I fear Cheng Yi's statement here merely followed the conventional view of later Confucians and did not fully capture the sage's intent in composing the classics. When it records 'murdered a ruler,' the murder itself is the crime — what need is there to inquire into the details of the murder? Military expeditions should proceed from the Son of Heaven; when it records 'attacked a state,' the attack itself is the crime — what need is there to inquire into the details of the attack? The sage transmitted the Six Classics solely to rectify the human mind — solely to preserve the Principle of Heaven and remove selfish desires. Regarding matters of preserving the Principle of Heaven and removing selfish desires, he sometimes spoke of them, or responded to people's questions, speaking to each according to their capacity, yet was reluctant to say too much, fearing people would seek truth only in words. Hence he said: 'I wish to speak no more.' As for all matters of indulging selfish desires and destroying the Principle of Heaven, how could he detail them for people to see? That would be encouraging disorder and leading people to wickedness. Therefore Mencius said: 'In the school of Confucius, no one discussed the affairs of Lords Huan and Wen — that is why later generations have no tradition of it.' This is the house-rule of the Confucian school. Later Confucians have only studied the learning of the hegemons, which is why they want to know all manner of schemes and stratagems — it is purely a mind of profit and advantage, the exact opposite of the sage's intent in composing the classics. How can they possibly think it through?" He then sighed and said: "Unless one has attained the virtue of Heaven, it is not easy to discuss this!"

He further said: "Confucius said: 'I can still find the gaps in the historical texts.' Mencius said: 'It is better to have no Documents at all than to believe everything in them. From the chapter on the Completion of the War, I accept only two or three passages.' When Confucius edited the Documents, for the four or five hundred years from Tang and Yu through the Xia, there are only a few chapters — were there truly no other events? Yet his record stops here. The sage's intent can be seen. The sage only wished to eliminate excessive writing; later Confucians only wish to add more."

Ai said: "The sage composed the classics solely to remove selfish desires and preserve the Principle of Heaven. Regarding events from the Five Hegemons downward, it is indeed so that the sage did not wish to detail them for people. But as for events before Yao and Shun — why are there so few records of these?"

The Master said: "The age of Fu Xi and the Yellow Emperor was remote, and those who transmitted its traditions were few. This is also understandable. The character of that time was one of utter purity, simplicity, and plainness, completely devoid of ornament or embellishment. This is the governance of high antiquity, which later ages cannot match."

Ai said: "But works like the Three Tombs were transmitted. Why did Confucius delete them?"

The Master said: "Even if they were transmitted, as times changed they were no longer appropriate. As customs became more open and culture more elaborate, by the end of the Zhou dynasty, even to change to the customs of the Xia or Shang was no longer feasible, let alone those of Tang and Yu, let alone those of Fu Xi and the Yellow Emperor. Yet though the governance differed, the Way was one. Confucius traced back to Yao and Shun in transmission, and took Wen and Wu as his immediate model. The institutions of Wen and Wu are the Way of Yao and Shun, but because they governed according to their times, their policies and decrees were already different. Even the achievements of the Xia and Shang, applied to the Zhou, already had incongruities. Hence 'the Duke of Zhou wished to combine the ways of the Three Kings, but where they did not fit, he thought and pondered, day into night.' How much less could the governance of high antiquity be implemented again? This is surely something the sage may set aside."

He further said: "To devote oneself exclusively to non-action, unable to govern according to the times as the Three Kings did, insisting on implementing the customs of high antiquity — this is the learning of Buddhism and Daoism. To govern according to the times, but unable to base it entirely on the Way as the Three Kings did, implementing it with a mind of profit and advantage — this is the work of the hegemons and below. The Confucians of later ages, with all their discussing back and forth, have only managed to learn the methods of the hegemon."

He further said: "The governance of Tang and Yu and before cannot be recovered — it may be set aside. The governance from the Three Dynasties downward cannot serve as a model — it may be deleted. Only the governance of the Three Dynasties can be practiced. Yet those in the world who discuss the Three Dynasties do not understand the root but only attend to the branches — and so even this cannot be recovered."

Ai said: "Earlier Confucians discussed the Six Classics and considered the Spring and Autumn Annals to be history. History specifically records events, and its nature may ultimately differ somewhat from the other Five Classics."

The Master said: "Spoken of in terms of events, it is called history; spoken of in terms of the Way, it is called a classic. Events are the Way; the Way is events. The Spring and Autumn Annals is also a classic; the Five Classics are also history. The Changes is the history of Fu Xi; the Documents is the history of Yao, Shun, and after; the Rites and Music are the history of the Three Dynasties. Their events are the same, their Way is the same — what difference could there be?"

He further said: "The Five Classics are also just history. History illuminates good and evil and provides lessons and warnings. Good that can serve as a model — its traces are preserved to show the pattern. Evil that can serve as a warning — the warning is preserved while the events are deleted to prevent wickedness."

Ai said: "Preserving traces to show the pattern is preserving the natural state of the Principle of Heaven. Deleting events to prevent wickedness is checking selfish desires at their inception — is this right?"

The Master said: "The sage's intent in composing the classics was certainly nothing other than this. Yet one should not be rigidly attached to the words and phrases."

Ai further asked: "If evil that can serve as a warning is preserved in warning while events are deleted to prevent wickedness, why alone in the Odes were the songs of Zheng and Wei not deleted? Earlier Confucians said 'what is evil can serve to restrain people's dissolute inclinations' — is this so?"

The Master said: "The Odes as we have them are no longer the original Confucian school text. Confucius said: 'Banish the music of Zheng, for the music of Zheng is licentious.' He also said: 'I hate the way the music of Zheng corrupts the elegant music.' 'The music of Zheng and Wei is the music of states in ruin.' This is the house-rule of the Confucian school. The three hundred poems Confucius selected were all what is called elegant music — all could be performed in the suburban temples, all could be performed in the villages. All served to propagate harmony and peace, to cultivate and nurture virtue, and to transform customs. How could such poems be there? That would be encouraging licentiousness and leading people to wickedness. These must have been added after the Qin burning of the books by later Confucians to fill out the count of three hundred. Licentious and dissolute words are what the common people most love to spread — this is true even today in the lanes and alleys. 'What is evil can restrain people's dissolute inclinations' — this is a case of seeking an explanation and not finding one, and so fabricating a justification."

Postscript by Xu Ai:
Ai, having been submerged in the old theories, was at first truly startled and unsettled upon hearing the Master's teaching, finding no way in. Afterward, having listened for a long time, he gradually learned to turn inward and put things into practice, and only then came to believe that the Master's learning is the true transmission of the Confucian school — all else being byways and dead ends. For instance, that 'the investigation of things' is the effort of 'making the intentions sincere,' that 'understanding goodness' is the effort of 'making oneself sincere,' that 'exhaustively investigating principle' is the effort of 'fully developing one's nature,' that 'following the path of inquiry and study' is the effort of 'honoring virtuous nature,' that 'broad learning in culture' is the effort of 'restraining oneself with ritual,' that 'refinement' is the effort of 'singleness' — all such propositions at first seemed incompatible. But after long thought, before I knew it I was dancing with joy.

The above was recorded by Yue Ren.

The following was recorded by the disciple Lu Cheng.

Lu Cheng asked: "Regarding the effort of 'concentrating on one thing' — if when reading one concentrates entirely on reading, and when receiving a guest one concentrates entirely on receiving the guest, can this be called 'concentrating on one thing'?"

The Master said: "If one lusts after beauty, one concentrates entirely on lusting after beauty; if one is greedy for wealth, one concentrates entirely on being greedy for wealth — can this be called 'concentrating on one thing'? This is what is called chasing after things, not concentrating on one thing. To concentrate on one thing is to concentrate solely on the Principle of Heaven."

Someone asked about establishing one's resolve.

The Master said: "Simply in every thought to seek to preserve the Principle of Heaven — this is establishing one's resolve. If one can keep this ever in mind, over time the mind will naturally become focused and concentrated, like what the Daoists call 'forming the sacred embryo.' When this thought of the Principle of Heaven is constantly preserved, one will gradually advance to the beautiful, the great, the sagely, and the divine — all simply through preserving, nourishing, and extending this single thought."

"When your daily effort feels confused and distracted, then practice quiet sitting. When you feel too lazy to read, then go ahead and read. This is also applying the medicine according to the illness."
"In dealing with friends, strive always to place yourself below them, and you will gain benefit. If you place yourself above them, you will be harmed."

Meng Yuan had the faults of self-righteousness and love of fame. The Master repeatedly reproved him. One day, just after he had been sternly rebuked, a friend was presenting his recent spiritual efforts for the Master's assessment. Yuan interjected from the side: "This is just like finding my old family valuables again."

The Master said: "Your illness has flared up again." Yuan's expression changed, and he seemed about to argue.

The Master said: "Your illness has flared up again." He then explained: "This is the great root of illness in your entire life. It is like having a plot of ground with a great tree planted in it — all the moisture of rain and dew, all the strength of the soil's veins, only nourish this great root. Even if you try to plant good grain around it, the leaves above block it and the roots below strangle it — how can anything grow? You must cut down this tree, leaving not a single fiber of root, before you can plant good seed. Otherwise, no matter how much you plow and fertilize, you are only nourishing this root."

Someone asked: "The proliferation of writings in later ages — might this not also disorder true learning?"

The Master said: "The human mind and the Principle of Heaven form a seamless whole. When the sages and worthies put this into writing, it was like painting a portrait or conveying a spirit-likeness — merely showing people the general form and outline, so that from this they might seek the reality. As for the vital spirit, the manner and bearing, the laughter and movement — these are inherently beyond what writing can convey. The writings of later ages take what the sages painted and copy, trace, and imitate it, arbitrarily analyzing, adding, and embellishing to show off their skill. The further they go from the truth, the more they miss it."

Someone asked: "The sage responds to change without limit. Does he perhaps study and prepare for things in advance?"

The Master said: "How could one study and prepare for so many things? The sage's mind is like a clear mirror — it is simply one brightness, responding to whatever comes and reflecting everything. There is never a form already past still lingering in it, nor a form not yet arrived already present in it. What later generations study and prepare for is exactly this — and this is why they greatly diverge from the sage's learning. The Duke of Zhou created the rites and music to civilize the world — something a sage could do. Why did Yao and Shun not do all this, leaving it for the Duke of Zhou? Confucius edited and transmitted the Six Classics to instruct all future ages — something a sage could do. Why did the Duke of Zhou not do it first, leaving it for Confucius? From this we know that when a sage encounters a particular time, only then does he do a particular thing. One should only worry that the mirror is not bright — not that things cannot be reflected. Studying and preparing for events is also a kind of reflecting when the time comes. But students must first cultivate the effort of making the mirror bright. Students should only worry that this mind is not yet bright — not that events cannot be fully responded to."

Someone said: "Then what about the statement: 'In the undifferentiated void without any sign, the ten thousand phenomena are already fully present'?"

The Master said: "This statement is fine in itself. But if one does not look at it correctly, it too becomes problematic."

"Moral principles have no fixed location and no limit. What I say to you — you must not think that having gained a little, that is all there is. Even after ten years, twenty years, fifty years of further discussion, there would still be no end."

On another day, he further said: "In goodness, even Yao and Shun — yet above Yao and Shun, goodness has no limit. In evil, even Jie and Zhou — yet below Jie and Zhou, evil has no limit. Had Jie and Zhou not died, would their evil have stopped there? If goodness had a limit, why did King Wen 'gaze toward the Way as if he had not yet seen it'?"

Someone asked: "In quiet moments I feel my state of mind is good, but as soon as I encounter affairs it is different. Why is this?"

The Master said: "This is because you only know how to cultivate stillness but do not apply the effort of overcoming the self. In this case, when you encounter affairs you will inevitably collapse. One must be tempered and refined through actual affairs before one can stand firm, before one can be stable in stillness and stable in activity alike."

Someone asked about the effort of "reaching the higher levels."

The Master said: "Later Confucians, the moment their teaching touches on what is refined and subtle, say 'reaching the higher levels is not yet appropriate for study' and insist on speaking only of 'lower learning.' This divides 'lower learning' and 'reaching the higher levels' into two separate things. What the eyes can see, the ears can hear, the mouth can speak of, and the mind can think about — all these belong to 'lower learning.' What the eyes cannot see, the ears cannot hear, the mouth cannot speak of, and the mind cannot think about — this belongs to 'reaching the higher levels.' It is like planting a tree: cultivating and watering it is 'lower learning'; as for the growth that occurs day and night, the spreading and flourishing of branches — this is 'reaching the higher levels.' How can human effort predetermine that? Therefore, all that can be worked on and spoken about belongs to 'lower learning'; 'reaching the higher levels' is found only within 'lower learning.' Everything the sages have said, however refined and subtle, all belongs to 'lower learning.' Students need only apply their effort within 'lower learning,' and they will naturally 'reach the higher levels.' There is no need to seek a separate effort for 'reaching the higher levels.'"

Someone asked: "How does one apply effort to 'refinement' and 'singleness'?"

The Master said: "'Singleness' is the guiding principle of 'refinement'; 'refinement' is the effort of 'singleness.' It is not that apart from 'refinement' there is a separate 'singleness.' The character 'refined' derives from 'rice' — let me use rice as an analogy. To want the rice to be purely clean and white is the meaning of 'singleness.' But without the effort of 'refinement' — the pounding, winnowing, sifting, and selecting — it cannot become purely clean and white. The pounding, winnowing, sifting, and selecting are the effort of 'refinement,' yet their purpose is only to bring the rice to pure whiteness. Learning broadly, questioning thoroughly, thinking carefully, discerning clearly, and practicing earnestly — all are the effort of 'refinement' in pursuit of 'singleness.' Similarly, 'broad learning in culture' is the effort of 'restraining oneself with ritual'; 'the investigation of things' and 'the extension of knowledge' are the effort of 'making the intentions sincere'; 'following the path of inquiry and study' is the effort of 'honoring virtuous nature'; 'understanding goodness' is the effort of 'making oneself sincere.' There is no second explanation."
"Knowledge is the beginning of action; action is the completion of knowledge. The learning of the sage is but one effort — knowledge and action cannot be divided into two things."

"Qi Diao Kai said: 'I am not yet able to have confidence in this.' The Master was pleased with him. When Zilu made Zigao the steward of Bi, the Master said: 'You are injuring another man's son.' When Zeng Dian expressed his aspiration, the Master approved of him. The sage's intent can be seen in these."

Someone asked: "When the mind is at rest in quiet preservation, can this be called 'the state of equilibrium before the emotions are aroused'?"

The Master said: "People today who practice preserving the mind only manage to settle the vital energy. When they are quiet, it is only the energy that is quiet — this cannot be called 'the state of equilibrium before the emotions are aroused.'"

The questioner said: "'Before the emotions are aroused' is itself 'equilibrium' — might this not also be the effort of seeking 'equilibrium'?"

The Master said: "The only true effort is to remove selfish desires and preserve the Principle of Heaven. In stillness, thought after thought remove selfish desires and preserve the Principle of Heaven; in activity, thought after thought remove selfish desires and preserve the Principle of Heaven. Do not be concerned with whether you are quiet or not. If you rely on that quietness, not only will you gradually develop the fault of preferring stillness and disliking activity, but many ailments will merely lie hidden beneath the surface and never be truly eliminated. When events arise, they will flourish again as before. Take following principle as the priority — how could one then not be quiet? Take quietness as the priority — one may not necessarily be able to follow principle."

Someone asked: "When the Confucian disciples expressed their aspirations, Zilu and Ran Qiu took up governance, and Gongxi Chi took up rites and music — all very practical. Yet when Zeng Dian spoke, his seemed like something trivial. Why did the sage approve of him? What was his meaning?"

The Master said: "The three others had fixed expectations and predetermined goals. Having fixed expectations, one is biased toward one side — able to do this but not necessarily that. Zeng Dian's state of mind had no fixed expectations — it was simply 'acting according to whatever position one is in, without wishing for anything beyond it: in a position among barbarians, acting according to that situation; in a position of hardship, acting according to that situation — entering nowhere without being at ease.' The three others were what is called 'vessels' — having a limited function. Zeng Dian had the quality of 'not being a mere vessel.' However, the talents of the three others were each brilliantly accomplished — they were not like those in the world who speak emptily without substance. Therefore the Master also approved of each of them."

Someone asked: "My knowledge and understanding are not progressing. What should I do?"

The Master said: "Learning must have a root and foundation. One must exert effort from the root, and gradually 'advance by filling each hollow as it comes.' The Daoist analogy of the infant is also apt. When an infant is in its mother's womb, it is pure vital energy — what knowledge does it have? After birth, it first learns to cry; then later it can smile; then later still it can recognize its parents and siblings; then later it can stand, walk, grasp, and carry — and eventually there is nothing in the world it cannot do. All this is because its vital essence daily grows more abundant, its physical strength daily grows stronger, and its intelligence daily opens more fully. It is not that from the day of birth one can seek and investigate everything. Therefore there must be a root and foundation. The sage 'positions Heaven and Earth, and nurtures the ten thousand things' — yet this too is cultivated from 'the state of equilibrium before joy, anger, sorrow, and pleasure are aroused.' Later Confucians, not understanding the teaching of 'the investigation of things,' see that the sage knows everything and can do everything, and wish from the very first step to study and master it all. How is this possible?"

He further said: "Establishing one's resolve and applying effort is like planting a tree. When it is just a root-sprout, there are as yet no branches. When it has a trunk, there are as yet no branches. After branches come leaves; after leaves come flowers and fruit. When first planting the root, just keep cultivating and watering it. Do not think about branches; do not think about leaves; do not think about flowers; do not think about fruit. What use is such idle speculation? As long as you do not neglect the effort of cultivation, need you worry that there will be no branches, leaves, flowers, and fruit?"

Someone asked: "I cannot understand what I read in books. What should I do?"

The Master said: "This is because you are only seeking through the literal meanings, and so you cannot understand. In that case, you would be better off with the old style of learning — at least they manage to read extensively and explain things. But even though they can explain things with perfect clarity, they gain nothing from it their whole lives. One must apply effort on the substance of the mind. Whenever something is not clear to you or you cannot carry it out in practice, you should turn back and examine it in your own mind — then you can understand. The Four Books and Five Classics merely speak of this substance of the mind. This substance of the mind is what is called the Way. When the substance of the mind is clear, the Way is clear — there is nothing else. This is the essential starting point of learning."

"The spiritual intelligence of the mind is never obscured; all principles are complete within it, and all affairs issue from it. There is no principle outside the mind, and no affair outside the mind."

Someone asked: "Master Zhu Xi said: 'What constitutes learning for a person is simply the mind and principle.' What do you think of this statement?"

The Master said: "The mind is nature; nature is principle. The use of the word 'and' between them, I fear, unavoidably implies they are two separate things. Students should carefully discern this for themselves."

Someone said: "Everyone has this mind, and the mind is principle. Why then do some do good and others do evil?"

The Master said: "The mind of an evil person has lost its original substance."

Someone asked: "'Analyzing it so as to be exhaustively precise without confusion, and then synthesizing it so as to be completely comprehensive without remainder' — what about this statement?"

The Master said: "I fear this is also not quite complete. How can this principle be divided by analysis? And what need is there to piece it together? When the sage spoke of 'refinement and singleness,' that in itself is exhaustive."
"Self-examination is preservation during times of activity; preservation is self-examination during times of inactivity."

Lu Cheng once asked about Lu Xiangshan's teaching of doing one's work on human feelings and the changes of affairs.

The Master said: "Apart from human feelings and the changes of affairs, there are no affairs at all. Joy, anger, sorrow, and pleasure — are these not human feelings? From seeing, hearing, speaking, and moving to wealth and honor, poverty and lowliness, hardship and adversity, life and death — all are the changes of affairs. The changes of affairs are all within human feelings. The essential point lies only in 'achieving equilibrium and harmony.' Achieving equilibrium and harmony lies only in 'being watchful over oneself when alone.'"

Lu Cheng asked: "Do the names humaneness, righteousness, ritual propriety, and wisdom arise only after the emotions are aroused?"

The Master said: "Yes."

On another day, Lu Cheng said: "Are commiseration, shame, deference, and the sense of right and wrong the manifest virtues of our nature?"

The Master said: "Humaneness, righteousness, ritual propriety, and wisdom — these are the manifest virtues. Nature is one and nothing more. Considered as form and body, it is called Heaven. As sovereign and master, it is called the Lord. As flowing and operating, it is called destiny. As endowed in human beings, it is called nature. As governing the person, it is called the mind. When the mind is aroused: encountering one's father, it is called filial piety; encountering one's ruler, it is called loyalty. From here onward, the names extend infinitely — yet it is only one nature. It is like a person — one and nothing more. In relation to one's father, one is called a son; in relation to one's son, one is called a father. From here onward, the relations extend infinitely — yet it is only one person. One need only apply effort on one's nature. See the single character 'nature' clearly, and the ten thousand principles become luminously clear."

One day, discussing the effort of learning, the Master said: "In teaching people to learn, one cannot be one-sided. At the beginning stage, the mind is like a monkey and the thoughts like a wild horse — restless and impossible to tie down. One's thoughts and reflections are mostly on the side of selfish desires. Therefore one should first teach quiet sitting and the calming of thoughts. After a long time, once the mind and thoughts are somewhat settled, merely suspending them in empty quietness, like a withered tree or dead ashes, is also useless. Then one must teach self-examination and self-conquest. The effort of self-examination and self-conquest admits of no interruption at any time. It is like pursuing bandits — one must have the resolve to sweep them out and clear them away completely. During times of inactivity, take the selfish desires for beauty, wealth, fame, and the like, and pursue them one by one, rooting them out. One must pull up the root of the disease so it never arises again — only then can one be satisfied. Be always like a cat catching a mouse: one eye watching, one ear listening. The moment a single thought stirs, immediately overcome and eliminate it. Be decisive as cutting iron, tolerating no indulgence or leniency; give it no shelter, and leave it no escape route. Only this is truly applying effort; only this can sweep things out and clear them away completely. When there are no more selfish desires to overcome, the time of sitting in dignified repose will come of itself. Although it is said 'What need to think? What need to deliberate?' — this is not for beginning students. Beginning students must think. Self-examination and self-conquest are themselves the thinking of sincerity — it is only thinking of the Principle of Heaven. When the Principle of Heaven is completely pure, that is 'What need to think? What need to deliberate?'"

Lu Cheng asked: "There are people who are afraid of ghosts at night. What can be done about this?"

The Master said: "It is only because in ordinary times one has not been able to 'accumulate righteous deeds,' and so the mind has something it is ashamed of. Hence the fear. If one's conduct in daily life accords with the spirits and the luminous, what is there to fear?"

Zi Xin said: "Upright ghosts need not be feared. But I'm afraid that evil ghosts do not care whether a person is good or bad, so one cannot avoid fearing them."

The Master said: "How could evil ghosts bewitch an upright person? This very fear is itself a deviation of the mind — and so there is something that bewitches. It is not that a ghost bewitches the person; the mind bewitches itself. For example, if a person lusts after beauty, he is bewitched by the ghost of lust. If he is greedy for wealth, he is bewitched by the ghost of greed. If he is angry when he should not be angry, he is bewitched by the ghost of anger. If he fears what he should not fear, he is bewitched by the ghost of fear."
"Stability is the original substance of the mind — it is the Principle of Heaven. Activity and stillness are the conditions of what one encounters at a given time."

Lu Cheng asked about the similarities and differences between the Great Learning and the Doctrine of the Mean.

The Master said: "Zisi condensed the entire meaning of the Great Learning into the first chapter of the Doctrine of the Mean."

Someone asked: "Regarding Confucius's 'rectification of names,' earlier Confucians said it meant 'reporting to the Son of Heaven above and to the regional lords below, deposing Zhe and establishing Ying.' What do you think of this interpretation?"

The Master said: "I am afraid it would be difficult to proceed that way. How could it be that someone comes to you with utmost respect and courtesy, entrusting his government to you, and your first act is to depose him? Would this accord with human feeling or the Principle of Heaven? If Confucius was willing to serve in Zhe's government, he must have already found Zhe able to submit wholeheartedly and entrust the state to him. With the sage's abundant virtue and utmost sincerity, he would certainly have moved Zhe to realize that one cannot be a human being while being without a father. Zhe would surely have wept bitterly and rushed off to welcome his father back. The love between father and son is rooted in our Heavenly nature. If Zhe could repent so truly and deeply, how could Kuai Kui not be moved? Once Kuai Kui returned, Zhe would then offer up the state and request punishment for himself. Kuai Kui, already transformed by his son, would certainly refuse to accept, and would command Zhe to continue ruling. The ministers and people would also certainly wish to have Zhe as their ruler. Zhe would then publicly confess his crimes, petition the Son of Heaven, and notify the regional lords and feudal princes, insisting on yielding the state to his father. Kuai Kui, along with the ministers and people, would also all attest to Zhe's repentance and filial virtue, petitioning the Son of Heaven and notifying the regional lords, insisting on having Zhe as ruler. Thus, by collective mandate, Zhe would be made to resume the rulership of Wei. Having no choice, Zhe would follow the precedent of later 'retired emperors,' leading the ministers and people to honor Kuai Kui as Grand Duke, providing him with all material comforts and devoted care, and only then returning to his own position. Then ruler would be ruler, minister would be minister, father would be father, son would be son — names would be rectified and speech would be in order, and the whole world could be governed in one stroke. This is perhaps what Confucius's rectification of names would have looked like."

Lu Cheng was staying at the Court of State Ceremonial when suddenly a letter arrived from home saying his child was critically ill. Lu Cheng's mind was deeply troubled and distressed, and he could not bear it.

The Master said: "This is precisely the time to apply effort. If you let this moment pass, what use is leisurely discussion of learning at other times? It is precisely in such moments that one must temper and refine oneself. A father's love for his child is certainly the deepest of feelings, yet the Principle of Heaven also has its proper measure of equilibrium and harmony. To exceed this is selfish desire. In such situations, people mostly take it to be the Principle of Heaven that one should worry, and so they abandon themselves entirely to grief and anguish, not realizing they have already fallen into the state where 'having worries and anxieties, one cannot attain correctness.' In general, when the seven emotions are aroused, most err on the side of excess; few err on the side of deficiency. The moment there is excess, it is no longer the original substance of the mind. One must adjust and bring it to the mean. It is like mourning for one's parents — the child would certainly wish to weep himself to death on the spot, feeling this would satisfy his heart. Yet the rule says 'grief should not destroy one's health.' This is not the sage forcibly restraining people — the original substance of the Principle of Heaven has its own proper limits that cannot be exceeded. One need only recognize the substance of the mind, and naturally not a hair's breadth can be added or subtracted."

"One cannot say that 'the state of equilibrium before the emotions are aroused' is something all ordinary people possess. For substance and function share one source: if one has this substance, one has this function. If one has 'the equilibrium before the emotions are aroused,' then one also has 'the harmony of emotions aroused in due measure.' Since people today cannot attain 'the harmony of emotions aroused in due measure,' one must recognize that their 'equilibrium before the emotions are aroused' is also not fully realized."

"The words of the Changes are the six characters 'First nine: the dragon lies hidden; do not act.' The image of the Changes is the initial line. The transformation of the Changes is the value assigned to its line. The divination of the Changes is the application of its words."

"'The night spirit' is spoken of with reference to ordinary people. For a student who is able to apply effort, then whether or not there are affairs during the day, every moment is a time when this vital energy gathers and generates. For the sage, there is no need to speak of 'the night spirit.'"

Lu Cheng asked about the chapter on "retaining and losing" the mind.

The Master said: "'It goes out and comes in at no fixed time; no one knows its direction.' Though this is said with reference to the ordinary person's mind, students must also understand that the original substance of the mind is fundamentally like this — only then will the effort of retaining and preserving be free from error. One should not simply say that going out is losing and coming in is retaining. If we speak of the original substance, it fundamentally has no going out or coming in. If we speak of going out and coming in, then its thinking and functioning is 'going out.' Yet the master that governs is always luminously present here — how can there be any going out? Since there is no going out, how can there be any coming in? What Cheng Yi called 'the framework' is simply the Principle of Heaven and nothing more. Though one responds to affairs all day long, if one never departs from the Principle of Heaven, one is within the framework. If one departs from the Principle of Heaven, this is called 'being let loose,' this is called 'being lost.'"

He further said: "Going out and coming in are simply activity and stillness. Activity and stillness have no fixed starting point — how could they have a direction?"

Wang Jiaxiu asked: "Buddhism uses escape from birth and death to entice people into the Way. Daoism uses long life and immortality to entice people into the Way. Their intentions are not to make people do wrong. At their ultimate reach, they also perceive the upper portion of what the sage sees. Yet they are not the correct path to entering the Way. It is like officials today: some enter through the examinations, some through tribute, some through special appointment. They all end up as high officials, yet ultimately the irregular paths are not the correct route to office, and the gentleman does not take them. Buddhism and Daoism at their highest point are roughly the same as the Confucian. But they have the upper portion and lack the lower portion; in the end they are not as complete as the sage. Yet in their upper portion they share something, and this cannot be denied. Later Confucians, however, have only grasped the lower portion of the sage's teaching, which has been fragmented and lost its truth, degenerating into memorization and recitation, literary composition, pursuit of profit, and textual exegesis. These four kinds of scholars labor their whole lives with not the slightest benefit to their minds and persons. Compared to the Buddhists and Daoists who purify their minds, reduce their desires, and transcend worldly entanglements, they actually seem to fall short. Today's students need not first attack Buddhism and Daoism; they should simply devote themselves to the learning of the sage. When the sage's learning is illuminated, Buddhism and Daoism will naturally vanish. Otherwise, what we study ourselves may be something they would not even deign to consider — and yet we want them to condescend to our level. Would that not be difficult? My humble view is thus. What does the Master think?"

The Master said: "What you say is largely correct. But speaking of an 'upper portion' and 'lower portion' — this too reflects a biased perspective. If we consider the sage's Way of the great mean and utmost correctness, it penetrates from top to bottom as a single thread. What 'upper portion' or 'lower portion' can there be? 'One yin and one yang — this is called the Way.' But 'the humane see it and call it humaneness; the wise see it and call it wisdom.' 'The common people use it daily without knowing it — thus the Way of the gentleman is rare.' Humaneness and wisdom — can they not be called the Way? But when seen one-sidedly, there are defects."
"The yarrow stalks are certainly the Changes; the tortoise shell is also the Changes."

Someone asked: "When Confucius said King Wu had not yet achieved perfect goodness, was there perhaps some dissatisfaction?"

The Master said: "Given King Wu's position, it was naturally appropriate for him to act as he did."

The questioner said: "If King Wen had not died, what would have happened in the end?"

The Master said: "When King Wen was alive, the world already had two parts out of three under his influence. Had King Wen still been alive at the time of King Wu's campaign against Shang, he might not have needed to raise arms — the remaining one part would certainly have come over on its own. King Wen would simply have managed Zhouwang well, preventing him from indulging further in evil."

Someone asked about Mencius's statement that "holding to the middle without discretion is the same as holding to one extreme."

The Master said: "The middle contains only the Principle of Heaven — it is simply the Changes. It changes adaptively with the time — how can it be held fixed? One must act as appropriate to the time, and it is hard to predetermine a fixed rule. When later Confucians try to explain every principle without any gap and establish a fixed formula — this is precisely 'holding to one extreme.'"

Tang Xu asked: "Is establishing one's resolve a matter of constantly maintaining a good thought — of wanting to do good and remove evil?"

The Master said: "When a good thought is present, that is the Principle of Heaven. This thought is itself good — what further good need be thought of? This thought is not evil — what further evil need be removed? This thought is like the root and sprout of a tree. To establish one's resolve is simply to sustain this good thought perpetually. 'Following what the heart desires without transgressing the rules' is simply the resolve having reached full maturity."

"In spirit, virtue, speech, and action, the general principle is that collecting inward should be primary, while outward expression comes only when unavoidable. This is true of Heaven, Earth, human beings, and all things alike."

Someone asked: "What kind of person was Wang Tong (Wenzhongzi)?"

The Master said: "Wang Tong came close to being a sage 'in complete form but in miniature.' It is a pity he died so young."

The questioner asked: "But what about his transgression of continuing the classics?"

The Master said: "Continuing the classics also cannot be entirely condemned."

The questioner pressed further. After a long silence, the Master said: "The more I reflect, the more I appreciate the line: 'Only the skilled craftsman knows the bitterness in his own heart.'"
"Xu Luzhai's saying that Confucians should put making a living first is also misleading."

Someone asked about the Daoist concepts of primal energy, primal spirit, and primal essence.

The Master said: "These are just one thing. In its flowing aspect, it is called energy; in its condensed aspect, it is called essence; in its marvelous functioning, it is called spirit."

"The original substance of joy, anger, sorrow, and pleasure is naturally equilibrium and harmony. The moment you attach the slightest personal intention to them, they become excessive or deficient — and that is selfish desire."

Someone asked about the passage "on the day one has wept, one does not sing."

The Master said: "The substance of the sage's mind is naturally like this."

"In overcoming the self, one must sweep things out and clear them away completely, not leaving a single hair's breadth. If even a hair's breadth remains, then all manner of evils will be drawn in by it."

Someone asked about the New Book on Pitches and Tubes.

The Master said: "Students should attend to what is most urgent. Even if one masters these calculations perfectly, it may be of no use. One must first have the foundation of rites and music in one's mind before one can proceed. For instance, that book speaks of using many tubes to test the vital energy of the seasons. But at the exact moment of the winter solstice, the ashes in the tubes may fly at slightly different times. In that brief instant, how can one know which tube corresponds precisely to the moment of the winter solstice? One must first know in one's own mind when the winter solstice occurs. Here is where it breaks down. Students must first apply effort to the fundamental source of rites and music."

Yue Ren said: "The mind is like a mirror. The sage's mind is like a bright mirror; the ordinary person's mind is like a dim mirror. The recent theory of 'investigating things' is like using a mirror to reflect things — applying effort to the reflecting, not realizing the mirror is still dim. How can a dim mirror reflect anything? The Master's 'investigation of things' is like polishing the mirror to make it bright — applying effort to the polishing. Once it is bright, the reflecting is never abandoned either."

Someone asked about the refined and the coarse in the Way.

The Master said: "The Way has no refined or coarse — it is people's perception that has refined and coarse. It is like this room: when a person first enters, he only sees the general layout. After staying a while, the pillars and walls and such all become clearly visible one by one. After still longer, even the fine decorative patterns on the pillars all come into view. Yet it is still the same room."

The Master said: "Lately you gentlemen have few questions when you come to see me. Why is this? When people do not apply effort, each invariably thinks he already knows how to learn, and that he need only follow along and practice accordingly. They do not realize that selfish desires arise daily, like dust on the ground — if you do not sweep for a day, another layer accumulates. If one truly applies effort, one sees that the Way is inexhaustible. The deeper one explores, the deeper it becomes. One must make oneself thoroughly pure and luminous, without a single hair's breadth that is not penetrated — only then is it sufficient."

Someone asked: "Only after knowledge is fully extended can one speak of making the intentions sincere. But if one's knowledge of the Principle of Heaven and selfish desires is not yet complete, how can one apply the effort of overcoming the self?"

The Master said: "If a person truly and earnestly applies effort without ceasing, then regarding this mind: the subtleties of the Principle of Heaven will become more visible day by day, and the subtleties of selfish desires will also become more visible day by day. If one does not apply the effort of overcoming the self, one merely talks all day long — the Principle of Heaven will never reveal itself, nor will selfish desires ever reveal themselves. It is like walking on a road: you walk one stretch, and then you recognize one stretch. When you reach a fork in the road and have doubts, you ask, and then walk on. Gradually you can reach your destination. People today, regarding the Principle of Heaven they already know, are unwilling to preserve it; regarding the selfish desires they already know, are unwilling to remove them. They merely worry that they cannot know everything. They merely engage in idle discussion — what benefit is there? Wait until you have overcome the self to the point where there is no more selfishness to overcome, and then worry that you cannot know everything — it will not be too late even then."

Someone asked: "The Way is one and nothing more. Yet the ancients' discussions of the Way often disagree. Is there an essential approach to seeking it?"

The Master said: "The Way has no fixed form or substance; one cannot grasp and hold it. If one is restricted to seeking the Way in the literal meanings of texts, one is far from it. People today just speak of 'Heaven,' but have they truly seen Heaven? To say that the sun, moon, wind, and thunder are Heaven is not quite right; to say that people, things, grass, and trees are not Heaven is also not right. The Way is Heaven. If you recognize it, what is there that is not the Way? But people each recognize only what they see from their own corner, fixing on that as if the Way were only thus. That is why they disagree. If you turn inward and seek, finding the substance of your own mind, then at no time and no place is this Way absent. From ancient times to the present, without end and without beginning — what sameness or difference can there be? The mind is the Way; the Way is Heaven. Know the mind and you know the Way; know the Way and you know Heaven."

He further said: "You gentlemen, if you wish to truly see this Way, must recognize and confirm it in your own minds. Do not seek it outside — only then can you attain it."

Someone asked: "Must the names, categories, and numerical specifications of things also be studied first?"

The Master said: "One need only accomplish the substance of one's own mind, and the application will be within it.
