If one cultivates the substance of the mind and truly attains 'the equilibrium before the emotions are aroused,' then naturally there will be 'the harmony of emotions aroused in due measure,' and naturally there will be nothing one cannot do. But if one lacks this mind, even if one studies in advance all the names, categories, and numerical specifications of the world, they have nothing to do with oneself — they are mere decoration, and when the time comes, one cannot put them into practice. Yet it is not that one should ignore names, categories, and numerical specifications entirely. The key is to 'know what comes first and what comes last, and then one is near the Way.'"

He further said: "People should develop their talents according to their natural capacities — that is what they can truly do. Kui's talent for music, Ji's talent for agriculture — these were what their natures were suited for from the beginning. What accomplished them was simply ensuring that the substance of their minds was purely the Principle of Heaven. When all their functions issued from the Principle of Heaven, only then could they be called talents. Once they reach the point of being purely the Principle of Heaven, they can also become 'not mere vessels.' If Kui and Ji switched arts, they would surely also be capable."

He further said: "As in 'being in a position of wealth and honor, one acts as befits wealth and honor; being in a position of hardship and adversity, one acts as befits hardship and adversity' — all this is 'not being a mere vessel.' Only one who has cultivated the substance of the mind to correctness can do this."

"Rather than being a pond of several acres without a source, it is better to be a well of several feet with a living spring — its vitality is inexhaustible." At the time, the Master was sitting beside a pond, with a well nearby, and so he used this as an analogy for learning.

Someone asked: "The Way of the world has been declining daily. How can the atmosphere of high antiquity be perceived again?"

The Master said: "A single day is itself an entire cycle. When a person rises at dawn, before encountering any affairs, and the mind is clear and bright — this scene is like wandering in the time of Fu Xi."

Someone asked: "The mind tends to chase after things. What can be done?"

The Master said: "When the ruler sits in dignified serenity, and the six ministers each attend to their own duties, the world is well governed. The mind governs the five senses and must also be like this. Now when the eyes want to see, the mind chases after colors; when the ears want to hear, the mind chases after sounds. It is as if when the ruler wants to select officials, he goes and sits in the Board of Personnel himself; when he wants to deploy troops, he goes and sits in the Board of War himself. Not only would this undermine the dignity of the ruler, but the six ministers would also all fail in their duties."

"When a good thought arises and one is aware of it, one extends it. When an evil thought arises and one is aware of it, one checks it. The one who is aware, who extends, and who checks — this is the will. It is the Heavenly intelligence. The sage has only this; the student should preserve this."

Lu Cheng said: "The desire for beauty, wealth, fame, and such — these are clearly selfish desires. But how can idle thoughts and random musings also be called selfish desires?"

The Master said: "They all ultimately arise from the root of desiring beauty, wealth, fame, and the like. Trace them to their root and you will see. If you are quite certain in your mind that you would never have a thought of committing robbery, why is that? It is because you fundamentally have no such inclination. If your inclinations toward wealth, beauty, fame, and profit were all eliminated just like your inclination toward robbery — all extinguished — and only the radiant original substance of the mind remained, what idle thoughts would there be? This is 'being utterly still and unmoving.' This is 'the equilibrium before the emotions are aroused.' This is 'being vast and impartial.' Then naturally 'when stimulated, one penetrates all things.' Naturally 'when aroused, all is in due measure.' Naturally 'things come and are responded to accordingly.'"

Someone asked about the phrase "the will is paramount and the vital energy is secondary."

The Master said: "This means 'where the will goes, the vital energy also goes.' It does not mean 'paramount' and 'secondary' in the sense of supreme and subordinate. 'Maintaining one's will' includes nourishing the vital energy within it. 'Not doing violence to the vital energy' also involves maintaining one's will. Mencius was correcting Gaozi's one-sidedness, which is why he presented it in this reciprocal manner."

Someone asked: "Earlier Confucians said: 'The Way of the sage necessarily descends and humbles itself. The words of the worthy necessarily reach upward and elevate themselves.' What do you think?"

The Master said: "Not so. If that were the case, it would be hypocrisy. The sage is like Heaven — there is nowhere that is not Heaven. Above the three luminaries is Heaven; below the nine depths of earth is also Heaven. How has Heaven ever descended and humbled itself? This is what is called 'greatness that transforms.' The worthy is like a mountain peak — he maintains his height and nothing more. But one of a hundred fathoms cannot reach up to become a thousand; one of a thousand fathoms cannot reach up to become ten thousand. The worthy never reaches up and elevates himself. To reach upward and elevate oneself would be hypocrisy."

Someone asked: "Cheng Yi said 'one should not seek equilibrium before the emotions are aroused,' yet Li Yanping taught students to 'observe the atmosphere before the emotions are aroused.' What do you make of this?"

The Master said: "Both are correct. Cheng Yi was concerned that people would seek a 'middle' before the emotions are aroused, treating equilibrium as a concrete thing — like what I previously called mistaking the settled state of one's vital energy for equilibrium. Therefore he directed people to apply effort only to nourishing and self-examination. Li Yanping was concerned that people would have no starting point for their effort, so he directed them to constantly observe the atmosphere before the emotions are aroused, making them fix their gaze on this alone, incline their ears to this alone — this is precisely the effort of 'being cautious about what is unseen, apprehensive about what is unheard.' Both are the ancients' unavoidable words to guide people."

Lu Cheng asked: "Regarding the equilibrium and harmony of joy, anger, sorrow, and pleasure — ordinary people certainly cannot possess them in their completeness. But in a single minor affair where joy or anger is appropriate, if ordinarily one has no undue inclination toward joy or anger, and when the occasion arises one responds in due measure — can this be called equilibrium and harmony?"

The Master said: "In a single instance and a single affair, it may indeed be called equilibrium and harmony. Yet it cannot be called the Great Foundation and the Universal Way. Human nature is entirely good; equilibrium and harmony are what everyone originally possesses — how can it be said that they are absent? But since the ordinary person's mind is obscured, although its original substance does manifest from time to time, these are only intermittent gleams — not its complete substance and great function. Only when there is nothing not in equilibrium can it be called the 'Great Foundation.' Only when there is nothing not in harmony can it be called the 'Universal Way.' Only the most sincere under Heaven can establish the Great Foundation of the world."

Lu Cheng said: "I am still not clear on the meaning of 'equilibrium.'"

The Master said: "This must be realized through personal experience of one's own mind. Words cannot convey it. 'Equilibrium' is simply the Principle of Heaven."

Lu Cheng asked: "What is the Principle of Heaven?"

The Master said: "Remove selfish desires, and you will recognize the Principle of Heaven."

Lu Cheng asked: "Why is the Principle of Heaven called 'equilibrium'?"

The Master said: "Because it is without bias or inclination."

Lu Cheng asked: "What is the atmosphere of being without bias or inclination?"

The Master said: "Like a bright mirror — its entire substance is luminous and transparent, without the slightest speck of dust attached."

Lu Cheng said: "Bias and inclination means having some attachment — as when one is attached to beauty, fame, or profit, the bias becomes visible. But before the emotions are aroused, when beauty, fame, and profit have not yet come into contact, how can one know there is bias?"

The Master said: "Although they have not yet come into contact, the mind's inclination toward beauty, fame, and profit was never truly absent. Since it was never absent, it can be called present. Since it is present, one cannot say there is no bias. It is like a person with malaria: although there are times when it does not flare up, the root of the disease was never removed, so one cannot call him a person without illness. One must sweep away all the selfish inclinations toward beauty, fame, profit, and the like, leaving not the slightest trace. When this mind in its entirety is vast and open, purely the Principle of Heaven — only then can it be called 'the equilibrium of joy, anger, sorrow, and pleasure before they are aroused.' Only then is it 'the Great Foundation of the world.'"

Someone asked: "The statement 'When Yan Hui died, the sage's learning was lost' — I cannot help but have doubts about this."

The Master said: "Only Yan Hui perceived the complete Way of the sage. This can be seen from his 'single deep sigh.' His saying 'The Master is good at leading people on step by step — he broadened me with culture and restrained me with ritual' — this was spoken after he had seen through to it. 'Broadening with culture' and 'restraining with ritual' — how are these 'good at leading people on'? Students must think about this. The complete substance of the Way — even the sage found it difficult to express to others. Students must cultivate and realize it themselves. Yan Hui's 'Though I wished to follow it, there was no way' carries the same meaning as King Wen's 'gazing toward the Way as if he had not seen it.' 'Gazing toward the Way as if not seeing it' is precisely true seeing. When Yan Hui died, the true lineage of the sage's learning was no longer fully transmitted."

Someone asked: "The master of the body is the mind; the spiritual awareness of the mind is knowledge; the activation of knowledge is intention; and what intention is directed toward is things. Is this correct?"

The Master said: "It is."
"Simply preserve this mind so that it is always present — that is learning. Thinking about past or future events — what benefit is there? It only lets the mind run loose."
"When speech is disordered and without sequence, this too is evidence that the mind is not present."

Shang Qian asked how Mencius's unmoved mind differed from that of Gaozi.

The Master said: "Gaozi forcibly seized hold of his mind, trying to make it not move. Mencius, through the accumulation of righteous deeds, naturally reached the point of an unmoved mind."

He further said: "The original substance of the mind is fundamentally unmoved. The original substance of the mind is nature; nature is principle. Nature is fundamentally unmoved; principle is fundamentally unmoved. The accumulation of righteous deeds is the restoration of the mind's original substance."

"When the ten thousand phenomena are vividly present, there is still the undifferentiated void without a sign. The undifferentiated void without a sign is itself the ten thousand phenomena vividly present. The undifferentiated void without a sign is the father of 'singleness.' The ten thousand phenomena vividly present are the mother of 'refinement.' Within 'singleness' there is 'refinement'; within 'refinement' there is 'singleness.'"
"There are no things outside the mind. When my mind gives rise to a thought of filial piety toward my parents, then filial piety toward my parents is itself a 'thing.'"

The Master said: "Among those today who study what I call the learning of 'the investigation of things,' many still drift into mere verbal and auditory learning. How much less can those who pursue only verbal and auditory learning be expected to turn toward this? The discrimination between the Principle of Heaven and selfish desires is so subtle that one must constantly and diligently examine and overcome oneself before one gradually perceives it. Even now, in the space of a single conversation, though one speaks only of the Principle of Heaven, who knows how many selfish desires have already arisen in the mind in fleeting moments? There are those that steal forth without one's knowledge. Even when one exerts oneself to examine them, they are not easily detected — how much less when one merely talks? People today merely discuss the Principle of Heaven and then set it aside without following it; they discuss selfish desires and then set them aside without removing them. Is this the learning of 'investigating things' and 'extending knowledge'? The learning of later ages, at its extreme, amounts to nothing more than the effort of 'snatching at righteousness from the outside.'"

Someone asked about "the investigation of things."

The Master said: "'Investigate' means 'rectify.' It is to rectify what is incorrect, in order to return it to its correctness."

Someone asked: "Does 'knowing where to rest' mean knowing that the highest good resides only in one's own mind and was never external — and after this one's resolve is settled?"

The Master said: "Yes."

Someone asked: "Does the investigation of things apply effort only during activity?"

The Master said: "The investigation of things makes no distinction between activity and stillness. Stillness is also a 'thing.' Mencius's phrase 'there must always be something one is attending to' means that whether in activity or stillness, there is always something to attend to."

"The difficulty of the entire effort lies in 'investigating things' and 'extending knowledge' — this is precisely the work of 'making the intentions sincere.' Once the intentions are sincere, the mind is largely rectified of itself, and the person is largely cultivated of itself. Yet 'rectifying the mind' and 'cultivating the person' each have their own points of application. 'Cultivating the person' pertains to the already-manifest side; 'rectifying the mind' pertains to the not-yet-manifest side. When the mind is rectified, there is equilibrium; when the person is cultivated, there is harmony."

"From 'investigating things' and 'extending knowledge' all the way to 'bringing peace to the world,' it is all just one 'manifesting luminous virtue.' Even 'loving the people' is part of the work of 'manifesting luminous virtue.' 'Luminous virtue' is the virtue of this mind — it is humaneness. The humane person takes Heaven, Earth, and the ten thousand things as one body. If a single thing fails to find its proper place, that represents an incompleteness in my humaneness."
"If one speaks only of 'manifesting luminous virtue' without speaking of 'loving the people,' one falls into Buddhism and Daoism."
"The highest good is one's nature. Nature originally has not the slightest evil — hence it is called 'the highest good.' To 'rest' in it is simply to restore its original state."

Someone asked: "Once I know that the highest good is my own nature, that my nature is complete in my mind, and that my mind is the place where the highest good rests, then I will no longer confusedly seek it outside, and my resolve will be settled. Being settled, I will not be agitated and thus will be still. Being still and not recklessly moving, I will be at peace. Being at peace, my entire mind will be focused on this one point, thinking through every possibility, determined to attain this highest good — this is being able to deliberate and thereby attain it. Is this correct?"

The Master said: "In general outline, this is also right."

Someone asked: "Cheng Yi said: 'The humane person takes Heaven, Earth, and the ten thousand things as one body.' Then why is Mo Di's doctrine of universal love not considered humaneness?"

The Master said: "This is very difficult to put into words. You gentlemen must realize it through personal experience. Humaneness is the principle of the ceaseless creative production of the universe. Although it pervades all things, with no place it is not, yet in its flowing and generating, there is a natural gradation. Because of this gradation, production is ceaseless. It is like the winter solstice when a single yang is born — from this single yang, it gradually increases to six yangs. Without the birth of this single yang, how could there be six? The same is true of yin. Because there is gradation, there is a starting point. Because there is a starting point, there is life. Because there is life, there is ceaselessness. Take a tree: when it first sprouts, that is where the life-impulse begins. From sprouting it grows a trunk; from the trunk grow branches and leaves — and so it lives and never ceases. Without the sprout, how could there be trunk, branches, or leaves? The ability to sprout depends on there being a root below. With a root there is life; without a root there is death. Without a root, how could there be sprouting? The love between parent and child, between siblings — this is where the life-impulse of the human mind begins, like the tree's sprouting. From this one extends humaneness to the people, and love to all things — this is growing trunk, branches, and leaves. Mo Di's universal love without distinctions treats his own father and brothers the same as strangers — and so there is no starting point. Without sprouting, one knows there is no root. Without a root, there is no ceaseless life. How can this be called humaneness? Filial piety and brotherly respect are the root of humaneness — this means the principle of humaneness generates from within."

Someone asked: "Li Yanping said: 'According with principle and without selfish mind.' How do 'according with principle' and 'without selfish mind' differ?"

The Master said: "The mind is principle. 'Without selfish mind' is itself 'according with principle.' Not yet 'according with principle' means there is a selfish mind. If one separates mind and principle in speaking of them, I fear this is also not quite right."

The questioner further asked: "The Buddhists, regarding all the selfish feelings and desires of the world, remain completely unattached. They seem to be without selfish mind. Yet they outwardly abandon human relationships — this seems not 'according with principle.'"

The Master said: "It is all one and the same thing. Everything they do is simply to accomplish their own selfish ends."

The following was recorded by the disciple Xue Kan.

Kan asked: "Maintaining one's resolve should be like having a pain in one's heart. When one's entire mind is on the pain, where is the leisure to engage in idle talk or meddle in others' affairs?"

The Master said: "For the beginning student, applying effort in this way is fine. But one must understand that the spiritual awareness of the mind 'goes out and comes in at no fixed time; no one knows its direction.' The spiritual luminosity of the mind is originally like this, and only then does one's effort have a proper basis. If one merely clings to it rigidly, I fear this too may produce a fault in one's effort."

Kan asked: "If one focuses exclusively on nourishing and preserving without attending to inquiry and study, one may mistake desire for principle. What then?"

The Master said: "A person must understand what learning is. Inquiry and study are themselves part of nourishing. If one does not pursue inquiry and study, it is only because one's resolve to nourish is not sincere enough."

Kan asked: "What does it mean to 'understand what learning is'?"

The Master said: "Ask yourself: for what purpose do you learn? What are you learning?"

Kan said: "I have often heard the Master's teaching that learning is learning to preserve the Principle of Heaven. The original substance of the mind is the Principle of Heaven. Recognizing the Principle of Heaven is simply ensuring that in one's own mind there are no selfish intentions."

The Master said: "If so, then one need only overcome selfish intentions and that is all. Why worry about not distinguishing principle from desire?"

Kan said: "I am precisely afraid of not recognizing these selfish intentions clearly."

The Master said: "This is simply because your resolve is not sincere enough. When your resolve is sincere, eyes and ears are all focused on this. How could there be any difficulty in recognition? 'The sense of right and wrong is something all people have' — it need not be sought outside. Inquiry and study are simply verifying what one's own mind perceives. It is not that apart from the mind there is some other perception."

The Master asked the friends present: "How has your effort been going recently?"

One friend described a state of vacant brightness.

The Master said: "This is just describing a scene."

Another friend narrated the differences between past and present.

The Master said: "This is just describing results."

Both friends were perplexed and asked for guidance.

The Master said: "The effort we should apply today is simply to ensure that our resolve to do good is genuine and sincere. When this resolve is genuine — seeing good one immediately moves toward it, having faults one immediately corrects them — this is genuine effort. In this way, selfish desires diminish daily and the Principle of Heaven becomes more manifest daily. If one merely seeks beautiful scenes or talks about results, this is the ailment of fostering growth and chasing outward — it is not the proper effort."

The friends reading books together often picked criticisms of Zhu Xi.

The Master said: "If this is done with a deliberate intention of finding differences, it is wrong. The places where my teaching differs from Zhu Xi's are at the very first step — a hair's breadth of difference leading to a divergence of a thousand miles. These cannot go undistinguished. But my mind and Zhu Xi's mind are not different. As for his other textual explanations, wherever they are clear and appropriate — how could one change a single word?"

Xi Yuan asked: "Sagehood can be attained through learning. Yet Bo Yi and Yi Yin, compared to Confucius, ultimately differ in talent and capacity. In what sense are they equally called sages?"

The Master said: "What makes a sage a sage is solely that his mind is purely the Principle of Heaven, without any admixture of selfish desires — like what makes pure gold pure: simply that its color is sufficient, without any admixture of copper or lead. When a person is purely the Principle of Heaven, he is a sage; when gold reaches sufficient color, it is pure. Yet sages' talents also differ in magnitude, just as gold differs in weight. Yao and Shun are like ten thousand taels; King Wen and Confucius like nine thousand; Yu, Tang, and King Wu like seven or eight thousand; Bo Yi and Yi Yin like four or five thousand. Their talent differs, but in being purely the Principle of Heaven they are the same — all may be called sages. Just as gold differs in weight but in sufficient color they are the same — all may be called pure gold. Five thousand taels placed among ten thousand share the same color; Bo Yi and Yi Yin placed beside Yao and Confucius share the same purity. What makes gold pure lies in color, not weight. What makes a sage lies in the Principle of Heaven, not talent. Therefore even an ordinary person, willing to learn and making his mind purely the Principle of Heaven, can become a sage — like one tael of gold compared to ten thousand: though the weight differs vastly, in reaching sufficient color it can be without shame. Hence 'Everyone can become a Yao or Shun.' The student need only remove selfish desires and preserve the Principle of Heaven — like refining gold to achieve sufficient color. If the gold's color lacks only a little, the refining is light and success easy. The more color falls short, the harder the refining. People's endowments vary in clarity, and their relation to the Way ranges from knowing easily to learning with advantage to knowing with difficulty — but their achievement is one. Later generations, not knowing the foundation of sagehood is purely the Principle of Heaven, have sought it through knowledge and ability, thinking they must master all the sage's knowledge one by one. Instead of applying effort to the Principle of Heaven, they exhaust themselves drilling into books, researching names, and mimicking traces. The more knowledge broadens, the more desires grow; the greater the abilities, the more the Principle of Heaven is obscured. It is like seeing someone with ten thousand taels of pure gold — instead of refining one's own color to match its purity, one throws in tin, lead, copper, and iron. The weight increases but the color declines, until in the end there is no gold left."

Yue Ren, who was beside him, said: "The Master's analogy is sufficient to dispel the confusion of fragmented learning. It is of great benefit to later students."

The Master further said: "In our effort, we should seek only daily reduction, not daily increase. Reducing one part of selfish desire is restoring one part of the Principle of Heaven. How light and free! How simple and easy!"

Shi De asked: "The Master's teaching on 'the investigation of things' is clear and simple — everyone can see it. Yet Zhu Xi, with his extraordinary brilliance, failed to perceive this. Why?"

The Master said: "Zhu Xi had great spirit and force of character. From his early years he was determined to carry on the past and open the way for the future, so he directed all his effort toward research and writing. Had he first applied himself to personal cultivation, he would naturally have had no leisure for such things. After his virtue had matured, if he were truly concerned about the Way not being illuminated — like Confucius retiring to edit the Six Classics, simplifying the complex for the guidance of later students — he would not have needed much research. Zhu Xi wrote extensively in his early years and only repented in his later years. He did things in reverse."

Shi De said: "His late-life repentance can be seen in statements like: 'The settled text I established before was in error.' And: 'Even having read all those books, what benefit is there to my own affairs?' And: 'This has nothing whatsoever to do with guarding books and clinging to words.' It was at this point that he finally regretted the errors of his earlier efforts, and turned to personal cultivation."

The Master said: "Indeed. This is where Zhu Xi is unsurpassable. He had great strength — once he repented, he immediately changed course. Unfortunately he died not long after, and the many errors of his lifetime were never corrected."

Kan was pulling weeds among the flowers, and remarked: "How is it that in Heaven and Earth, good is so hard to cultivate and evil so hard to remove?"

The Master said: "You simply have not yet cultivated or removed anything."

After a moment, the Master said: "This way of viewing good and evil, thinking from the perspective of the physical body, leads to error."

Kan did not understand.

The Master said: "The creative vitality of Heaven and Earth — flowers and grasses are all the same. When has there ever been a distinction of good and evil among them? When you want to admire flowers, you consider flowers good and grass evil. When you want to use grass, you consider grass good again. Such good and evil are all generated by the likes and dislikes of your own mind — hence I say it is an error."

Kan said: "Then is there neither good nor evil?"

The Master said: "The absence of good and evil is the stillness of principle. The presence of good and evil is the movement of vital energy. When one is not moved by vital energy, there is neither good nor evil — this is called the highest good."

Kan said: "The Buddhists also speak of neither good nor evil. How does this differ?"

The Master said: "The Buddhists, being fixated on the absence of good and evil, therefore abandon everything and cannot govern the world. When the sage is without good and evil, it is simply that he has 'no personal preferences or aversions' — he is not moved by vital energy. Yet he 'follows the king's Way' and 'arrives at the ultimate standard,' naturally 'following the Principle of Heaven throughout.' He naturally engages in 'assisting and completing the transformative work of Heaven and Earth.'"

Kan said: "If the grass is not evil, then it should not be removed."

The Master said: "That is precisely the Buddhist and Daoist view. If the grass is in the way, what harm is there in removing it?"

Kan said: "But then is this not making preferences and aversions?"

The Master said: "Being without preferences and aversions does not mean having absolutely no likes and dislikes — that would be a person without awareness. What is meant by 'not making' them is that one's likes and dislikes all follow principle, without attaching an extra degree of personal intention. In this way, it is as if there were no likes and dislikes at all."

Kan said: "Removing weeds — how is this 'following principle without attaching personal intention'?"

The Master said: "The grass is in the way; principle dictates it should be removed. Remove it and be done. If it happens not to be removed right away, do not let it burden your mind. If you attach personal intention, then the substance of the mind becomes encumbered, and there will be many agitations of vital energy."

Kan said: "Then good and evil have nothing to do with external things?"

The Master said: "They reside only in your mind. Following principle is good; being moved by vital energy is evil."

Kan said: "So ultimately things have no good or evil."

The Master said: "It is so in the mind, and it is so in things as well. Later Confucians, not understanding this, abandon the mind and chase after things. They have misunderstood the learning of 'investigating things,' spending all day in outward pursuit, achieving nothing more than 'snatching at righteousness from the outside' — acting without awareness, practicing without examination."

Kan said: "'Like loving a lovely sight, like hating a hateful smell' — what about this?"

The Master said: "This is precisely following principle entirely. It is what the Principle of Heaven naturally requires. There is no personal intention making likes or dislikes."

Kan said: "But 'like loving a lovely sight, like hating a hateful smell' — how is this not intention?"

The Master said: "This is sincere intention, not selfish intention. Sincere intention is simply following the Principle of Heaven. Even following the Principle of Heaven, one cannot attach even a hair's breadth of extra intention. Hence 'when there is resentment, fondness, or delight, the mind cannot attain its correctness.' One must be 'vast and impartial' before it is the mind's original substance. Understanding this, one understands 'the equilibrium before the emotions are aroused.'"

Bo Sheng said: "The Master said: 'The grass is in the way; principle dictates it should be removed.' How is this different from what you called 'thinking from the perspective of the physical body'?"

The Master said: "You must verify this in your own mind. When you want to remove the grass, what is your state of mind? Zhou Dunyi did not cut the grass before his window — what was his state of mind?"

The Master said to the students: "In learning, one must have a guiding principle. Only then does one's effort have a place to land. Even when there are interruptions, it is like a boat that has a rudder — one pull and it rights itself. Otherwise, even if one engages in study, it is merely 'snatching at righteousness from the outside' — acting without awareness, practicing without examination. This is not the Great Foundation or the Universal Way."

He further said: "When you truly see it, you can explain it horizontally or vertically and it is all correct. If you understand in one area but not another, you have simply not yet seen it."

Someone said that because of family obligations, he could not avoid the burden of preparing for the civil service examinations, and this hindered his learning.

The Master said: "If preparing for the examinations for the sake of one's parents is a hindrance to learning, then is farming to feed one's parents also a hindrance to learning? An earlier worthy said: 'The only worry is that it might displace one's aspiration.' The only fear is that one's aspiration for true learning is not genuinely sincere."

Chong Yi asked: "My mind is usually busy. I am busy even when I have affairs, and busy even when I have none. Why is this?"

The Master said: "The vital mechanism of Heaven and Earth never pauses for an instant. Yet because there is a governing master, it is neither too early nor too late, neither too fast nor too slow. Though there are a thousand changes and ten thousand transformations, the governing master remains constant and settled. Human beings receive this and live. When the governing master is settled, one is like the Heavenly rotation — ceaseless. Though one responds to ten thousand changes, one is always at ease. This is what is called 'The Heavenly sovereign is serene; the hundred members all obey.' Without a governing master, the vital energy simply rushes about wildly. How could one not be busy?"

The Master said: "The great disease of learning is the love of fame."

Kan said: "In years past I thought this disease had grown lighter in me. But upon recent careful examination, I find it has not diminished at all. Need it be outwardly seeking recognition from others? Even being pleased upon hearing praise and dejected upon hearing criticism — is this not the disease manifesting?"

The Master said: "Exactly so. Fame and substance are opposites. When the resolve for substance grows one part heavier, the resolve for fame grows one part lighter. When one is entirely devoted to substance, there is no resolve for fame at all. If one's resolve for substance is like hunger seeking food and thirst seeking drink, where would there be any leisure for loving fame?"

He further said: "'He was anxious lest he die and his name not be honored' — here 'honored' should be read in the falling tone, carrying the same meaning as 'when reputation exceeds reality, the gentleman is ashamed of it.' When reality does not match one's name — during life there is still time to make amends, but after death there is no remedy. 'Reaching forty or fifty without being heard of' — this means not having heard the Way, not being without reputation. Confucius said: 'That is merely fame, not true attainment.' How would he encourage people to seek mere reputation?"

Kan often felt regret.

The Master said: "Remorse and awakening are the medicine for curing disease. But what is valuable is that one actually changes. If one dwells on it and lets it linger in the mind, then the medicine itself produces a new disease."

De Zhang said: "I have heard the Master's analogy of the sage to pure gold, with weight representing the sage's capacity, and refining representing the student's effort — this is most profound and apt. But to say Yao and Shun are ten thousand taels while Confucius is nine thousand — this I find unsettling."

The Master said: "This is again thinking from the perspective of the physical body, and so you are arguing about weights on behalf of the sages. If you do not think from the perspective of the physical body, then Yao and Shun's ten thousand taels is not too much, and Confucius's nine thousand is not too little. Yao and Shun's ten thousand taels is simply Confucius's; Confucius's nine thousand is simply Yao and Shun's. Originally there is no distinction of self and other — and this is why they are called sages. One speaks only of 'refinement and singleness,' not of quantity. The key is only that this mind be purely the Principle of Heaven — in that they are the same, and all are called sages. As for strength and force of character, how could they be entirely identical? Later Confucians only compare quantities — and thus drift into profit-seeking. If one eliminates the comparing mind, and each person exerts the full measure of his own strength and spirit solely in the effort of making this mind purely the Principle of Heaven, then everyone possesses it in himself, each one complete and perfect. The great can achieve greatness, the small can achieve their own measure of perfection — without relying on external aspiration, nothing is lacking. This is the genuine work of understanding goodness and making oneself sincere. Later Confucians do not understand the sage's learning. Not knowing to recognize and extend the innate knowing and innate ability of their own minds, they instead seek to know what they do not know and do what they cannot do — solely aspiring to what is lofty and grand. Not knowing that their own minds are those of a Jie or Zhou, they presume at every turn to do the work of a Yao or Shun. How can this possibly succeed? They labor year after year until old age and death, never knowing what they have actually accomplished. How lamentable!"

Kan asked: "Earlier Confucians took the mind's stillness as its substance and the mind's activity as its function. What do you think?"

The Master said: "The mind cannot be divided into substance and function according to activity and stillness. Activity and stillness are matters of time. Speaking from the side of substance, function is within substance. Speaking from the side of function, substance is within function. This is what is meant by 'substance and function share one source.' If one says that in stillness one can see the substance and in activity one can see the function, that is acceptable."

Someone asked: "How is it that 'the supremely wise and the lowest of the low cannot be changed'?"

The Master said: "It is not that they cannot be changed — it is that they are unwilling to change."

Someone asked about the chapter where "Zixia's disciples asked about making friends."

The Master said: "Zixia speaks of the friendships of younger students; Zizhang speaks of the friendships of mature persons. If used well, both are correct."

Zi Ren asked: "'To learn and at due times to practice what one has learned — is this not a pleasure?' Earlier Confucians interpreted 'learning' as 'imitating what the earlier awakened ones have done.' What do you think?"

The Master said: "Learning is learning to remove selfish desires and preserve the Principle of Heaven. In the course of removing selfish desires and preserving the Principle of Heaven, one naturally takes the earlier awakened ones as models, examines ancient teachings, and engages in much questioning, deliberation, reflection, discernment, and self-conquest. But all this is only to remove selfish desires from this mind and preserve the Principle of Heaven of this mind. If one merely says 'imitating what the earlier awakened ones have done,' this only describes one aspect of learning and seems to place the emphasis on seeking externally. 'Practicing at due times' — 'sitting like a personator of the dead' does not mean one practices only sitting; it means that when sitting, one practices this mind. 'Standing like one performing a sacrifice' does not mean one practices only standing; it means that when standing, one practices this mind. 'Pleasure' is the pleasure of 'moral principles delighting the mind' — the human mind naturally delights in moral principles, as the eye naturally delights in color and the ear naturally delights in sound. Only because it is obscured and burdened by selfish desires does this delight sometimes cease. When selfish desires are daily removed, moral principles daily permeate and saturate the mind — how can one not feel pleasure?"

Guo Ying asked: "Zengzi's 'three daily self-examinations' are certainly earnest. But might this be the effort he used before he had heard about 'the one thread'?"

The Master said: "'The one thread' was the Master's observation that Zengzi had not yet grasped the essential point of his effort, and so he told him. If a student can truly apply effort through loyalty and reciprocity, is this not 'the one thread'? 'One' is like the root of a tree; 'thread' is like the branches and leaves. Without first planting the root, how can there be branches and leaves? Substance and function share one source — if substance is not yet established, how can function arise from it? To say that 'Zengzi, in his functioning, had already examined and practiced everything with precision, but did not yet know the oneness of the substance' — I fear this is not quite complete."

Huang Chengfu asked about the chapter "Which of you two is the better?"

The Master said: "Zigong learned much and remembered it all — he applied effort on what he heard and saw. Yan Hui applied effort on the ground of the mind. Therefore the sage asked this question to prompt him. Zigong's reply still remained on the level of knowledge and perception. Hence the sage sighed for him — this was not approval."
"Yan Hui's 'not transferring his anger and not repeating a fault' — this too was possible only because he had 'the equilibrium before the emotions are aroused.'"

"Those who plant trees must cultivate the root; those who cultivate virtue must nourish the mind. If you want the tree to grow tall, you must prune its excessive branches when it is young. If you want virtue to flourish, you must remove external diversions when you first begin to learn. If your external diversion is poetry and literature, then your vital spirit gradually leaks away into poetry and literature. The same is true of all external diversions."

He further said: "My teaching here is the effort of creating something from nothing. You gentlemen must have complete faith in it. It is simply establishing one's resolve. A student's single thought of aspiring to do good is like the seed of a tree. Simply do not force it and do not forget it; just keep cultivating it. Naturally it will grow day and night, its vitality will become more complete daily, and its branches and leaves will flourish daily. When a tree first begins to grow, it may already sprout excessive branches that must be pruned, so that the root and trunk can grow large. It is the same for beginning students. Therefore, establishing one's resolve requires single-minded concentration."

A discussion arose about the Master's students — how a certain person devoted his effort to nourishing and preserving, while another devoted his effort to perception and understanding.

The Master said: "One who focuses exclusively on nourishing daily perceives his own insufficiency. One who focuses exclusively on perception daily perceives his own surplus. He who daily perceives insufficiency daily gains more. He who daily perceives surplus daily has less."

Liang Rifu asked: "'Abiding in reverence' and 'exhaustively investigating principle' are two things, yet the Master regards them as one. How so?"

The Master said: "Between Heaven and Earth there is only this one thing. How can there be two? If you speak of the myriad particularities — three hundred rules of ceremony, three thousand rules of deportment — there are far more than two! Tell me: what is 'abiding in reverence'? What is 'exhaustively investigating principle'?"

Liang said: "'Abiding in reverence' is the effort of preserving and nourishing. 'Exhaustively investigating principle' is investigating the principles of things and affairs."

The Master said: "What are you preserving and nourishing?"

Liang said: "Preserving and nourishing the Principle of Heaven in this mind."

The Master said: "If so, then this is already 'exhaustively investigating principle.'" Then the Master asked: "And how does one 'investigate the principles of things and affairs'?"

Liang said: "For instance, in serving one's parents one must investigate the principle of filial piety; in serving one's ruler one must investigate the principle of loyalty."

The Master said: "Do the principles of loyalty and filial piety reside in the ruler and parent, or in one's own mind? If in one's own mind, then this is simply investigating the principle of this mind."

Then the Master asked: "And what is 'reverence'?"

Liang said: "It is simply 'concentrating on one thing.'"

The Master asked: "And what is 'concentrating on one thing'?"

Liang said: "For instance, when reading a book, concentrating entirely on reading. When dealing with an affair, concentrating entirely on that affair."

The Master said: "Then when drinking wine, concentrating entirely on drinking? When lusting after beauty, concentrating entirely on lust? This is chasing after things — what kind of 'abiding in reverence' is this?"

Liang asked for instruction.

The Master said: "The 'one' is the Principle of Heaven. 'Concentrating on one thing' is concentrating the mind on the Principle of Heaven. If you only know to 'concentrate on one thing' without knowing that the 'one' is principle, then when there are affairs you are chasing after things, and when there are no affairs you are attached to emptiness. Only when in both activity and inactivity your mind is entirely on the Principle of Heaven — then 'abiding in reverence' is itself 'exhaustively investigating principle.' Looking at 'exhaustively investigating principle' from the angle of concentration, we call it 'abiding in reverence.' Looking at 'abiding in reverence' from the angle of precision, we call it 'exhaustively investigating principle.' It is not that one 'abides in reverence' with one mind while 'investigating principle' with another. The names differ, but the effort is one and the same thing. It is like the Changes saying 'reverence to straighten the inner life, righteousness to square the outer life' — reverence is simply righteousness when there are no affairs; righteousness is simply reverence when there are affairs. These two phrases speak of one thing. As Confucius said 'cultivating oneself through reverence' — there is no need to add righteousness. As Mencius said 'accumulating righteousness' — there is no need to add reverence. Once you understand it, you can explain it any way you like and the effort is always the same. If you cling to the text and chase after sentences without recognizing the fundamental principle, things fragment and fall apart, and the effort has no place to land."

Someone asked: "How can 'exhaustively investigating principle' be the same as 'fully developing one's nature'?"

The Master said: "The substance of the mind is nature; nature is principle. Exhaustively investigating the principle of humaneness means truly wanting to be humane to the utmost. Exhaustively investigating the principle of righteousness means truly wanting to be righteous to the utmost. Humaneness and righteousness are nothing but our nature. Therefore, exhaustively investigating principle is fully developing one's nature. As Mencius said: 'Extend your feeling of commiseration, and humaneness becomes inexhaustible.' This is precisely the effort of exhaustively investigating principle."

Liang said: "An earlier Confucian said: 'Even a single blade of grass or tree has its principle, which must not go unexamined.' What about this?"

The Master said: "I have no leisure for that. You should first go and attend to your own nature and feelings. Only after you can fully develop human nature can you fully develop the nature of things." Liang was struck with awe and had an awakening.

Wei Qian asked: "How is knowledge the original substance of the mind?"

The Master said: "Knowledge is the spiritual aspect of principle. Considered from the angle of governing, it is called the mind. Considered from the angle of what is endowed, it is called nature. Young children all know to love their parents and all know to respect their elders. It is simply this spiritual capacity, unobstructed by selfish desires. Extend it fully and it is complete. Completeness is its original substance — it then is in accord with the virtue of Heaven and Earth. From the sage on down, none can be without obstructions. Therefore one must 'investigate things' in order to extend one's knowledge."

Shou Heng asked: "The Great Learning's effort is simply making the intentions sincere, and the effort of making intentions sincere is simply investigating things. Cultivating the person, regulating the family, ordering the state, and bringing peace to the world are all completed through making the intentions sincere. Yet there is also the effort of rectifying the mind — 'when there is resentment, fondness, or delight, the mind cannot attain its correctness.' Why?"

The Master said: "You must think this out for yourself. Understanding this, you will understand 'the equilibrium before the emotions are aroused.'"

Shou Heng asked again and again.

The Master said: "The effort of learning has shallow and deep levels. At first, if one does not sincerely and deliberately apply oneself to loving good and hating evil, how can one do good and remove evil? This sincere and deliberate application is making the intentions sincere. Yet one does not realize that the mind's original substance originally has nothing in it. If one keeps deliberately applying oneself to loving good and hating evil, this adds an extra layer of intention — and it is no longer 'vast and impartial.' The Documents say: 'Without personal preferences, without personal aversions' — this is the original substance. Therefore it says: 'When there is resentment, fondness, or delight, the mind cannot attain its correctness.' Rectifying the mind is simply, within the effort of making the intentions sincere, realizing in one's own mind-substance that it must always be 'like an empty mirror, like a level balance.' This is 'the equilibrium before the emotions are aroused.'"

Zheng Zhi asked: "'Vigilant caution is the effort for times when one does not know oneself; watchfulness in solitude is the effort for times when one alone knows' — what do you think of this?"

The Master said: "It is only one effort. When there are no affairs, it is still a state of 'knowing alone'; when there are affairs, it is also 'knowing alone.' If a person does not exert effort at this place of 'knowing alone,' but only works at what others can observe, this is hypocrisy — it is 'seeing a gentleman and only then feeling ashamed.' This place of 'knowing alone' is where sincerity first sprouts. Here, whether the thought is good or evil, there is no pretense. One right leads to all being right; one wrong leads to all being wrong. This is precisely the dividing line between the kingly and the hegemonic, between righteousness and profit, between sincerity and hypocrisy, between good and evil. Establish yourself here firmly, and you have rectified the source and clarified the spring — this is 'establishing sincerity.' The ancients' many efforts at making themselves sincere — their vital spirit and lifeblood — are entirely in this one point. Truly there is nothing more hidden, nothing more manifest; no time, no place; no beginning, no end — it is all just this one effort. If you now divide 'vigilant caution' into what you do not know yourself, the effort becomes fragmented and has gaps. Since vigilant caution is itself knowing, if you yourself do not know, who is being vigilant and cautious? This kind of understanding will lead you into the void of Chan Buddhism."

The questioner said: "If whether the thought is good or evil there is no pretense, then at the place of 'knowing alone' is there never a moment without thought?"

The Master said: "Vigilant caution is itself a thought. The thought of vigilant caution can never be suspended. If the mind of vigilant caution is even slightly absent, one is either in a stupor or has already drifted into evil thoughts. From dawn to dusk, from youth to old age — if you want to be without thought, that is not knowing, which is either being in a stupor or being withered wood and dead ashes."

Zhi Dao asked: "Xunzi said 'There is nothing better for nourishing the mind than sincerity.' Earlier Confucians criticized this. Why?"

The Master said: "This cannot simply be dismissed. The word 'sincerity' can be spoken of as effort: sincerity is the original substance of the mind, and seeking to restore its original substance is the effort of 'thinking on sincerity.' Cheng Hao's statement 'preserve it through sincerity and reverence' is also this meaning. The Great Learning says: 'Wishing to rectify their minds, they first made their intentions sincere.' Xunzi's words do have many problems, but one should not uniformly pick them apart looking for faults. In Mencius's saying 'enriching oneself through unrighteousness,' he took this from Yang Huo. Here we can see the great impartiality of the sage and worthy."

Xiao Hui asked: "Selfish desires are hard to overcome. What can be done?"

The Master said: "Bring me your selfish desires and I will overcome them for you."

He further said: "A person must have the resolve to work for his true self before he can overcome the self. Only by overcoming the self can one fulfill the self."

Xiao Hui said: "I do feel I have some resolve to work for myself, yet I cannot overcome myself. Why?"

The Master said: "Tell me what your resolve to work for yourself is like."

After a long pause, Hui said: "I have always wanted to be a good person, and considered this to be having resolve to work for myself. But now thinking about it, it seems I have only been working for the self of the physical body, not for my true self."

The Master said: "Has the true self ever been separate from the physical body? I fear you have not even been working for the self of the physical body. Tell me: what you call the physical self — is it not the eyes, ears, mouth, nose, and four limbs?"

Hui said: "Precisely. It is for these that the eyes want beauty, the ears want music, the mouth wants flavors, and the limbs want ease and pleasure. This is why I cannot overcome myself."

The Master said: "'Beautiful colors make the eyes blind; beautiful sounds make the ears deaf; fine flavors dull the palate; galloping and hunting drive one mad.' All these harm your eyes, ears, mouth, nose, and four limbs. How can they be for their sake? If you were truly working for the eyes, ears, mouth, nose, and four limbs, you would need to consider how the ears should hear, how the eyes should see, how the mouth should speak, and how the limbs should move. You must 'not look at what is contrary to ritual, not listen to what is contrary to ritual, not speak what is contrary to ritual, not move in ways contrary to ritual.' Only then do the eyes, ears, mouth, nose, and four limbs truly become your eyes, ears, mouth, nose, and four limbs. This is truly working for them. Now you spend all day chasing outward, pursuing fame and profit — this is all working for things external to the physical body. If you truly work for the eyes, ears, mouth, nose, and four limbs, wishing not to look, listen, speak, or move contrary to ritual — is it your eyes, ears, mouth, nose, and four limbs that can of themselves refrain? It must be through your mind. These acts of seeing, hearing, speaking, and moving are all acts of your mind. Your mind's seeing issues through the aperture of the eyes; your mind's hearing issues through the aperture of the ears; your mind's speaking issues through the aperture of the mouth; your mind's moving issues through the aperture of the four limbs. Without your mind, there would be no eyes, ears, mouth, nose. What is called your mind is also not merely that lump of flesh. If it were just that lump of flesh, then the dead — that lump of flesh is still there — why can they no longer see, hear, speak, or move? What is called your mind is that which can see, hear, speak, and move. This is nature; this is the Principle of Heaven. Having this nature, there can be life. The life-giving principle of this nature is called humaneness. This life-giving principle of nature: issuing through the eyes, it can see; issuing through the ears, it can hear; issuing through the mouth, it can speak; issuing through the four limbs, it can move. All of this is simply the Principle of Heaven generating and issuing forth. Because it governs the entire person, it is called the mind. The original substance of this mind was originally just the Principle of Heaven, originally without anything contrary to ritual. This is your true self. This true self is the master of the physical body. Without the true self, there is no physical body. Truly, having it means life; lacking it means death. If you truly work for the physical self, you must employ this true self. You must constantly preserve and protect the original substance of this true self, 'being cautious about what is unseen, apprehensive about what is unheard,' fearing the slightest harm might come to it. The moment even a hair's breadth of what is contrary to ritual stirs, it should be like a knife cutting or a needle pricking — unbearable until the knife is removed and the needle pulled out. This is truly having a resolve to work for oneself, and the strength to overcome oneself. What you have now is recognizing the thief as your own child. How can you then say you have the resolve but lack the strength?"

There was a student who had an eye ailment and was deeply anxious about it.

The Master said: "You value your eyes more than your mind."

Xiao Hui was fond of Buddhism and Daoism.

The Master admonished him: "I too from my youth was devoted to these two teachings. I believed I had attained something and considered Confucian learning not worth studying. Later, during my three years of exile, I perceived the learning of the sage — how simple, easy, and vast it is. Only then did I lament and repent having wasted thirty years of effort. In general, the learning of the two teachings, at its most subtle, differs from the sage's by only a hair's breadth. What you are now studying is merely their dregs, yet you are so self-satisfied and pleased with it. You are truly like an owl clutching a rotten mouse."

Hui asked about the subtlety of the two teachings.

The Master said: "I told you the sage's learning is simple, easy, and vast, yet you do not ask me about my awakening — you only ask about my regret."

Hui was ashamed and asked about the sage's learning.

The Master said: "You are now merely asking for the sake of asking. Wait until you have prepared a genuine resolve to become a sage, then come and I will tell you."

Hui asked again and again.

The Master said: "I have already told you everything in a single sentence, yet you still do not understand."

Liu Guanshi asked: "What is 'the equilibrium before the emotions are aroused'?"

The Master said: "You need only be cautious about what is unseen and apprehensive about what is unheard, nourishing this mind until it is purely the Principle of Heaven — then you will naturally perceive it."

Guanshi asked for a brief indication of its atmosphere.

The Master said: "It is like a mute who has eaten a bitter melon — he cannot describe it to you. If you want to know the bitterness, you must eat it yourself."

At that time Yue Ren was beside him and said: "This is indeed what it means that true knowledge is itself action."

All the friends present at that time had a moment of awakening.

Xiao Hui asked about the way of life and death.

The Master said: "Know day and night, and you know life and death."

Hui asked about the way of day and night.

The Master said: "Know day, and you know night."

Hui said: "Is there something about day that one does not know?"

The Master said: "Can you truly know day? Rising in a daze, eating in a stupor, acting without awareness, practicing without examination — all day in a muddled state. This is only dreaming during the day. Only when in every breath there is nourishment, in every blink there is preservation, when this mind is alert and luminous, and the Principle of Heaven is not interrupted for a single instant — only then can you truly know day. This is Heavenly virtue. This is 'penetrating the way of day and night and thereby understanding.' What more is there to life and death?"

Ma Zixin asked: "Regarding 'the cultivation of the Way is called instruction' — the earlier commentary says 'the sage takes what is inherent in our nature and regulates it, establishing standards for the world, such as rites, music, punishments, and governance.' What do you think of this?"

The Master said: "The Way is nature, is destiny. It is originally complete and perfect — nothing can be added or subtracted, and it requires no embellishment. What need is there for the sage to 'regulate' it? That would make it something incomplete. Rites, music, punishments, and governance are methods for governing the world — they may indeed be called 'instruction.' But this is not Zisi's original meaning. If one follows the earlier commentary, why does the passage below — on entering the Way through instruction — set aside the sage's teachings of rites, music, punishments, and governance, and instead speak of a separate effort of vigilant caution and apprehension? That would make the sage's teachings an empty formality."

Zixin asked further.

The Master said: "Zisi speaks of nature, the Way, and instruction all from the fundamental source. What Heaven commands in people is called nature; following one's nature in action is called the Way; cultivating the Way through learning is called instruction. Following one's nature pertains to those who are sincere — what is called 'from sincerity to understanding, this is called nature.' Cultivating the Way pertains to those who seek sincerity — what is called 'from understanding to sincerity, this is called instruction.' The sage follows his nature in action — this itself is the Way. Below the sage, people cannot fully follow their nature. In relation to the Way they inevitably err by excess or deficiency. Therefore they must 'cultivate' the Way. Cultivating the Way means that the wise and talented are not permitted to go too far, and the foolish and unwilling are not permitted to fall short. Everyone must follow this Way — and thus the Way becomes 'instruction.' This 'instruction' carries the same meaning as in 'the Way of Heaven is the ultimate instruction' and 'wind, rain, frost, and dew are all instruction.' 'Cultivating' here is the same as in 'cultivating the Way through humaneness.' When a person can cultivate the Way, he can then avoid transgressing the Way and restore the original substance of his nature — this is also the sage's Way of following one's nature. Below, 'vigilant caution and apprehension' is the effort of cultivating the Way. 'Equilibrium and harmony' is restoring the original substance of one's nature. This is like the Changes saying 'exhaustively investigating principle, fully developing one's nature, to arrive at destiny.' 'Equilibrium and harmony bringing all things to their proper places' is fully developing one's nature and arriving at destiny."

Huang Chengfu asked: "Earlier Confucians considered Confucius's answer to Yan Hui's question about governing a state to be the establishment of an eternal standard for all ages. What do you think?"

The Master said: "Yan Hui already embodied the sage in complete form. Regarding the great root and great source of governing a state, he was already fully equipped. The Master, who knew him deeply through long acquaintance, did not need to discuss these. He spoke only of institutional forms and cultural expressions. Such matters should not be neglected — they must be exactly right before things are perfect. Moreover, one should not, because one's own fundamental capacity is sound, become negligent in matters of precaution. Hence the need to 'banish the music of Zheng and keep flatterers at a distance.' Yan Hui was a person who overcame himself and turned inward, applying effort to virtue. Confucius, fearing that in external details and minor points he might be somewhat negligent, supplemented what was lacking. Had it been someone else, the Master would have needed to speak of 'governance depending on the right people, obtaining people through one's own character, cultivating character through the Way, cultivating the Way through humaneness,' the 'Universal Way,' the 'nine standards,' and the many efforts of 'making oneself sincere.' Only then could the task be accomplished. This is the truly eternal standard for all ages. Otherwise, if one merely adopts the calendar of Xia, rides in the carriage of Yin, wears the cap of Zhou, and performs the Shao dance — would the world thereby be well governed? Later people, seeing that Yan Hui was the foremost disciple and that this question was about 'governing a state,' took it to be a matter of supreme importance."

Cai Xiyuan asked: "In Zhu Xi's new edition of the Great Learning, 'investigating things and extending knowledge' precedes the effort of 'making the intentions sincere.' This seems to accord with the sequence of the opening chapter. But if we follow the Master's position of keeping the old text, then 'making the intentions sincere' comes before 'investigating things and extending knowledge.' I am still not at ease about this."

The Master said: "The effort of the Great Learning is simply 'manifesting luminous virtue.' 'Manifesting luminous virtue' is simply 'making the intentions sincere.' The effort of 'making the intentions sincere' is simply 'investigating things' and 'extending knowledge.' If one takes 'making the intentions sincere' as primary and then applies the effort of 'investigating things' and 'extending knowledge,' then the effort has a place to land, and doing good and removing evil are both aspects of 'making the intentions sincere.' In the new edition, one first investigates the principles of things and affairs — but this is vague and unfocused, with no basis whatsoever. One must add the word 'reverence' before it can be dragged back to the realm of mind and person. But ultimately it has no root. If one must add the word 'reverence,' why did the school of Confucius drop precisely this most essential word, leaving it for someone a thousand years later to supply? The point is precisely that taking 'making the intentions sincere' as primary makes the addition of 'reverence' unnecessary. This is why 'making the intentions sincere' is highlighted — it is precisely the essential starting point of all learning. To fail to discern this is truly a case of 'a hair's breadth of difference leading to an error of a thousand miles.' In general, the effort of the Doctrine of the Mean is simply 'making oneself sincere.' 'Making oneself sincere' at its utmost is 'supreme sincerity.' The effort of the Great Learning is simply 'making the intentions sincere.' 'Making the intentions sincere' at its utmost is 'the highest good.' The effort is altogether the same. To say that here one must supplement with 'reverence' and there one must supplement with 'sincerity' is adding legs to a snake."
